@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001:7.89-7.90
:citation_urn: urn:cts:CHS:Commentaries.AHCIP:Iliad.7.89-7.90.juP4xpn
:created_at: 2020-03-12T16:44:16.283Z
:updated_at: 2020-03-12T16:44:16.283Z

The memorial language imagined here in the wording of Hector corresponds to the formulaic language of poetry written down on stone in the form of epigrams. So, Homeric diction shows here an awarenes of the genre of epigrammatic poetry. But this genre needed the technology of writing only for the sake of recording a given epigrammatic poem, not for the sake of actually composing it. Therefore, the awareness of epigrammatic language in Homeric diction does not require us to think that the technology of writing was needed for either the composition or the performance of Homeric poetry.

---

The Achaeans, faced with Hectorâ€™s challenge, hesitate, I.07.092â€“093. Their hesitation seems to indicate that not one of them is really the â€˜best of the Achaeansâ€™. Finally, Menelaos is first to volunteer for a one-on-one duel with Hector, I.07.094â€“103. An absence of volunteers, Menelaos knows, would be *aklees* â€˜a thing without glory [*kleos*]â€™, I.07.100. It seems of course fitting for him to be the first, since his grievance against the Trojans over the abduction of Helen is primary, but the problem is that all the Achaean chieftains are aware of his inferiority to Hector, I.07.106, and so, fearing for his life, they restrain him from arming himself for a duel. Even the Master Narrator says outright that Hector was superior to Menelaos, I.07.104â€“105. Then Nestor goads the chieftains to take up the challenge of Hector, I.07.123â€“161, and his goading now prompts nine of these chieftains to volunteer, I.07.161â€“169: they are Agamemnon, Diomedes, the two Ajaxes, Idomeneus and Meriones, Eurypylos, Thoas, and Odysseus. It is significant that Nestorâ€™s words refer to these nine chieftains as *aristÄ“es PanakhaiÅn*, I.07.159. For a translation of this expression, the singular form *aristeus* of plural *aristÄ“es* first needs to be correlated with the verb *aristeuein*, which can be translated as â€˜strive to be the best, to be *aristos*â€™, as at Î™.06.208 and I.11.784. In the second of these two passages, I find it most significant that the referent is Achilles himself. An *aristeus*, then, is a man who strives to be the best, *aristos*. Correspondingly, the expression *aristÄ“es PanakhaiÅn* at I.07.159 must refer to â€˜men who strive to be the best of all the Achaeansâ€™.

Nestor, in speaking to the assembled Achaeans, prescribes that they build a Wall for the purpose of protecting both them and their ships from the attacks of the Trojans. This purpose is spelled out at I.07.338. What Nestor prescribes for the Achaeans to accomplish here at I.07.336â€“343 is then actually accomplished by them, as described at I.07.434â€“442, where the purpose of protecting both the Achaeans and their ships is restated, I.07.437. The details of the prescription and of the description supplement each other. For example, an important detail that is absent in the prescription is supplemented in the description: the word *teikhos* â€˜wallâ€™, referring to the overall structure that the Achaeans are building, is absent in the prescription, I.07.337, but this word is present in the description, I.07.436. Both in the prescription and in the description, at I.07.336â€“338 and at I.07.435â€“437 respectively, the Wall is linked to the collective tomb that the Achaeans are to build for their war dead: this tomb is located right next to the pyre where the bodies of the dead are cremated, I.07.337 and I.07.436.

What follows is epitomized from H24H 10Â§30. The cosmic river Okeanos is situated at the outermost limits of the world, which is encircled by its stream. The circular stream of the Okeanos flows eternally around the world and eternally recycles the infinite supply of fresh water that feeds upon itself: see I.14.246â€“246a, I.18.399, I.20.065. This mystical river Okeanos, surrounding not only the earth but even the seas surrounding the earth, defines the limits of the known world. Every evening, as the sun sets at sunset, it literally plunges into the fresh waters of this eternally self-recycling cosmic stream, I.08.485, and it is from these same fresh waters that the sun rises again every morning at sunrise, as here at I.08.421â€“423 as also at O.19.433â€“434. This cosmic river ÅŒkeanos, encircling the known world, is a boundary delimiting light from darkness, wakefulness from sleep, life from death. The movement of the sun both into and out from the waters of the ÅŒkeanos is envisioned as a cosmic model for an alternation between sleep and awakening, between death and rebirth.

Within these verses I.07.433â€“465 is a description of the building of the Achaean Wall at I.07.434â€“442 that matches the prescription given by Nestor at I.07.336â€“343. While the Wall is being built, I.07.434â€“442, the gods are watching, I.07.443â€“444, and Poseidon makes a speech to Zeus, I.445â€“453, indicating that this Achaean project is against his will and, presumably, against the will of Apollo. Poseidon is concerned that the kleos or epic â€˜gloryâ€™ of the Achaean Wall, I.07.451, will detract from the corresponding glory of the Trojan Wall that had been built by him together with Apollo for Laomedon, who had been king of Troy before Priam, I.07.452â€“453. Zeus responds with reassurances, I.07.454â€“464, reaffirming the *kleos* or epic â€˜gloryâ€™ that belongs to Poseidon, I.07.458 (Ïƒá½¸Î½ â€¦ÎºÎ»Î­Î¿Ï‚). In other words, Poseidon and Apollo will never lose the epic glory that is theirs because they built the Wall of Troy. And Zeus then utters a prophecy about the *teikhos* â€˜wallâ€™ of the Achaeans, I.07.461: it will be destroyed once the Achaeans leave the Trojan landscape, I.07.459â€“464. So the *kleos* or epic â€˜gloryâ€™ of the Achaean Wall, as signaled in the wording of Poseidon at I.07.451, will not destroy the *kleos* or epic â€˜gloryâ€™ that is owed to Poseidon and to Apollo for their building of the Trojan Wall. In terms of this formulation made by Zeus, it is not clear whether the Trojan Wall will later be utterly destroyed or simply damaged when the Achaeans finally conquer Troy. Such a distinction is relevant to a claim made in historical times by the inhabitants of New Ilion, which was in fact the Old Ilion, otherwise known simply as Troy: the people of Ilion maintained that their Wall had not been completely destroyed by the Achaeans in the Trojan War and that their city, despite all the destruction, had never been left completely abandoned. This claim is documented but rejected by Strabo 13.1.40 C599. See Point 7 of the anchor comment at I.09.328â€“333 about efforts of Aeolians to possess ancient Troy and its environs in the historical period.

Related forms in other Indo-European languages, however, help elucidate the meaning of *terpi*- as combined with *keraunÃ³s*. In the case of *keraunÃ³s*, we find in the Baltic and Slavic branches of Indo-European the parallel forms *perkÅ«nas* and *perunÅ­* respectively, both of which are nouns meaning â€˜thunderâ€™ and/or â€˜god of thunderâ€™. Although the Greek and the Baltic/Slavic roots here, **kerh2(uÌ¯)-* and **per(kw)-* respectively, are different in form, they are parallel in meaning, â€˜strikeâ€™, and the morphology of their suffixation is also parallel (GMP 194â€“195). This form, it can be argued, refers to the defining sacred moment when a thunderbolt strikes an oak tree: here the root of the *u*-stem noun *quercus*, from **perkwu*-, is **perkw*-, meaning â€˜strikeâ€™ (GMP 186). The momentum of the fighting between the Achaeans and Trojans is hanging in the balanceâ€”until high noon arrives, at which point Zeus decides to get out his golden *talanta* â€˜scalesâ€™, I.08.69, as he readies to weigh who will win and who will lose. In just a moment, the balance will be tipped in favor of the Trojans. As we see at I.08.070, Zeus had put two *kÃªre* â€˜portionsâ€™ at either end of the scales. Or, to say it etymologically, there are two â€˜slicesâ€™ that are being weighed at either end, since the noun *ká¸—r* is derived from the verb *keirein* â€˜cut, sliceâ€™. You can slice it both ways, life or death. Right from the start, though, the slicing is viewed negatively, and that is why at I.08.070 the two slices that Zeus weighs on the scales are already both viewed as â€˜slices of deathâ€™. For the moment, though, these slices are not yet really â€˜slices of deathâ€™, since the action is still only at the tipping point, and the outcome is supposedly still in the balance. But the negative connotations of the word *ká¸—r* in Homeric diction, which regularly means â€˜fated deathâ€™ in the singular, as at I.18.118, have already predetermined the prematurely negative view of the fate that now awaits the Achaeans. Once the tipping actually gets underway, the slices for the Achaeans now sink downward at I.08.073â€“074, while the slices for the Trojans lift upward at I.08.074. So now the â€˜slices of deathâ€™ are meant for the Achaeans, not for the Trojans. For the Achaeans, both original slices now mean death, and, in fact, the originally single slice on the Achaean side of the scales can now be viewed as many slices for the many fighters. Many of these fighters will die, and so the original *ká¸—r* or â€˜fate of deathâ€™ for the Achaeans cannot any longer be seen as a singularity. Now the slices can be viewed distributively: different Achaeans will get different slices of death, and that is why the single slice that had been pictured at each end of the scale at I.08.070 can now become the plural *kÃªres* â€˜slicesâ€™ of death for the Achaeans at I.08.073. Then at I.08.075 Zeus thunders from on high on top of Mount Ida, and he sends at I.08.075â€“076 a flaming thunderbolt toward the Achaeans. At I.08.076, the word for the thunderbolt is *selas*, meaning literally a â€˜flash of lightâ€™. We see here the first occurrence of the word *selas* â€˜flash of lightâ€™ in the *Iliad*. In occurrences to come, we will see that this powerful word signals the Will of Zeus.

@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001:8.78-8.117
:citation_urn: urn:cts:CHS:Commentaries.AHCIP:Iliad.8.78-8.117.oCQxKuH

What follows is a general commentary on these verses; what follows after that is an anchor comment on Nestorâ€™s entanglement and the poetics of evocation.

Seeing the lightning sent by Zeus, I.08.076, the Achaean chieftains are now thunderstruck with fear, I.08.076â€“077. Mentioned by name at I.08.078â€“079 as those chieftains who now retreat in terror are Idomeneus, Agamemnon, and the two Ajaxes. Only Nestor, it is said, does not retreat, though not because he does not want to: he simply cannot retreat because his chariot has been immobilized, I.08.080-086. The trace horse of Nestorâ€™s chariot team of three horses has been shot dead by Paris and has fallen down violently to the ground, I.08.080-086. The old hero, drawing his sword, is now struggling to cut himself loose from the *parÄ“oriai* â€˜tracesâ€™ that were connected to the fallen horse and that have now entangled the chariot team, I.08.087â€“088. This trace horse, not named, is analogous to the trace horse of Achilles, named Pedasos, who is killed at a much later point in the *Iliad*, in a scene of chariot fighting that takes place at I.16.466â€“476. In that scene, a spear throw by Sarpedon in the course of his chariot fight with Patroklos hits Pedasos instead of Patroklos, I.16.466â€“468. At I.16.471 and at I.16.474, the narrative there refers to Pedasos explicitly as the *parÄ“oros* â€˜trace horseâ€™ of a three-horse chariot team. As a trace horse, Pedasos is not attached to the yoke that attaches the other two horses to the chariot. This distinction is made clear at a slightly earlier moment, I.16.145â€“154, leading up to the chariot fight. At this moment, the premier chariot driver of Achilles, Automedon, is harnessing for Patroklos the war chariot of Achilles. On this chariot, Automedon and Patroklos will be riding off together as chariot rider and chariot fighter respectively. At this slightly earlier moment, we see that there are two immortal horses of Achilles, Xanthos and Balios, who are attached to the yoke of the chariot, I.16.148â€“149, while the mortal trace horse Pedasos is simply connected to the *parÄ“oriai* â€˜tracesâ€™, I.16.152. At this same moment, I.16.153, a significant detail is added about Pedasos: this horse had been captured once upon a time by Achilles when that hero killed the horseâ€™s former owner, who was EÃ«tion the father of Andromache. Then, at I.16.466â€“469, when Pedasos is killed by the spear-throw of Sarpedon and falls violently to the ground, the traces of this trace horse get entangled in the reins connected to the other two horses, I.16.470â€“471, and Automedon the chariot driver must free himself from the entanglement by drawing his sword and cutting the traces, thus severing the ties to the dead trace horse, Î™.16.472â€“475. Having noted what will happen in this future action, we now return to the present, I.08.087â€“088: so, what happens to Nestor as he struggles to cut himself loose from his entanglement? Well, meanwhile, the old heroâ€™s predicament has been spotted by Hector, who is now driving his own chariot at high speed toward Nestor, I.08.088â€“090, intending to attack him before Nestor can disentangle himself from his disabled chariot. As Hector charges ahead, he is holding on to the reins of his own chariot horses, since he is described at I.08.090 as the *hÄ“ni-okhos* â€˜chariot driverâ€™ for the moment, or, to translate the word more literally, as â€˜the one who holds on to the reinsâ€™. For the moment, then, it is the chariot fighter Hector and not his chariot driver who is here taking the initative of attempting a high-speed attack on Nestor. Hector is thus taking over here from his own chariot driver. As we are about to see, this driver is a hero named Eniopeus, who at this precise moment must be standing next to Hector on the platform of the speeding chariotâ€”but not driving the vehicle himself. This detail about Hector as the momentary chariot driver helps explain what happens later on. Eventually, Hectorâ€™s driver Eniopeus will be killed while apparently still standing on the chariot platform: it will happen at I.08.119â€“124, where Diomedes throws his spear at Hector but hits Eniopeus instead, who dies instantly and falls out of the chariot. In that context, we will see that Eniopeus is now and only now described explicitly as the *hÄ“ni-okhos* â€˜chariot driverâ€™, I.08.119. There is an irony here. If Eniopeus and not Hector had been driving the chariot when Diomedes threw his spear, it could have been Hector who got hit and killed. Having noted once again what will happen in the future action, we now return to the present. The Master Narrator goes on to say at I.08.090 that the entanglement of the old hero Nestor would surely have resulted in his death at the hands of Hectorâ€”had it not been for the intervention of the young hero Diomedes, I.08.091. Urging Nestor to leave behind his disabled chariot, Diomedes offers him an invitation: let the two heroes ride together on the new chariot of Diomedes and let them now counterattack Hector, I.08.092â€“112. And let the two *theraponte* â€˜attendantsâ€™ meanwhile take away the horses and the chariot of Nestor, taking them back to a zone of safety, I.08.109. The old hero agrees to the invitation, I.08.112. So, the two â€˜attendantsâ€™ now proceed to take away the chariot team of Nestor, I.08.113, and these two figures are identified here as Sthenelos, chariot driver of Diomedes, and Eurymedon, chariot driver of Nestor, I.08.114. Meanwhile the old hero Nestor joins Diomedes, mounting the platform of the young heroâ€™s chariot. And then he even takes the reins of the chariot of Diomedes in hand and drives the chariot himself, I.08.116â€“117. So, for the moment, Nestor takes over from Sthenelos as the designated charioteer of Diomedes.

@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001:8.78-8.117
:citation_urn: urn:cts:CHS:Commentaries.AHCIP:Iliad.8.78-8.117.hWxtPeW

This whole epic narrative about Nestorâ€™s entanglement and his rescue by Diomedes is evocative of another epic narrative where the old hero gets entangledâ€”and gets rescued this time by another young hero, his own son Antilokhos, from the onslaught of another enemy, the chariot fighter Memnon. In this other narrative, however, the son will die in the act of rescuing the father. He will be killed by Memnon. There is a reference to this other epic narrative in a song of Pindar, *Pythian* 6.28â€“42. The death of Antilokhos was also narrated in a part of the epic Cycle, the *Aithiopis*, attributed to Arctinus of Miletus, as we read in the plot-summary of Proclus p. 106 lines 4-6 (ed. Allen 1912). On the *epic Cycle*, see the inventory of Words and Ideas. And there is a passing reference to the death of Antilokhos in O.04.186â€“188. That said, it is important to add a clarification: to say that the Iliadic narrative about an entanglement experienced by Nestor is *evocative* of another epic narrative as found in the epic Cycle is not to say that the *Iliad* is referring to a pre-existing text. In poetic traditions that stem from an evolving process of recomposition-in-performance, as in the case of Homeric poetry, any act of referencing needs to be viewed in terms of the historical context for any given performance. What can work as a reference in one context may not work so wellâ€”or work at allâ€” in some other context. A performance that follows one epic version can referâ€”however indirectlyâ€”to another epic version, but only if those who hear the performance are expected to know both versions. Referencing can be direct, as when Sthenelos the chariot driver of Diomedes refers at I.02.119â€“130 to the role of these two heroes in the epic traditions of the Epigonoi, that is, The Sons-of-the-Seven-against Thebes. Or referencing can be indirect, as is the case here. The narrative about the entanglement of Nestor and his rescue by Diomedes is sure to have a special effect on those who already know of another narrative about a later entanglement of Nestor that leads to tragic consequences. So, the term *evocation* suits such indirect referencing. Viewed in this light, *evocation* in Homeric poetry can be defined simply as *a reference made not directly but only indirectly from one traditional context to another*. For another evocation of the epic moment when Nestorâ€™s chariot gets entangled and his son Antilokhos gets killed in an effort to save the old hero, see the comment on I.09.057â€“058.

:created_at: 2020-03-12T16:44:21.268Z
:updated_at: 2020-03-12T16:44:21.268Z

Unlike other heroes in Homeric narrative, Hector has a chariot drawn by four rather than two horses. There are Athenian connotations to be seen here. As we learn from the Parian Marble, *FGH* 239 section 10, the Athenians claimed that Erikhthonios, a prototypical hero of Athens, was the inventor of the four-horse chariot on the occasion of the first chariot race held at the first Panathenaic festival in 1505/4 BCE. Correspondingly, there is a prototypical hero of Troy who is likewise Erikhthonios: is is said at I.20.219 and I.202.30 that this Erikhthonios was son of Dardanos and father of Tros, who in turn was the ancestor of Anchises father of Aeneas. In this light, we may compare the reference at I.05.271 to four chariot horses owned by Anchises. It can be argued that these details about four-horse chariots are relevant to Athenian agenda at work during an Athenian phase of Homeric transmission.

Hector here is said to be *atalantos* or â€˜equalâ€™ to Ares. This kind of equating of a hero with the war god will figure prominently in future scenes of mortal combat. Relevant are previous scenes of mortal combat involving Diomedes: see the comments at I.05.438, I.05.440â€“442, I.05.459. Besides Hector, as here at I.08.215 another hero who will be pointedly described as â€˜equal to Aresâ€™ is Patroklos. Besides sharing such an epithet, Hector and Patroklos will also be sharing the armor of Achilles: first it is Patroklos who wears this armor when he goes off to fight as a substitute for Achilles; and then Hector will wear it after he kills Patroklos.

@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001:8.220-8.227
:citation_urn: urn:cts:CHS:Commentaries.AHCIP:Iliad.8.220-8.227.yoL6BEJ

The ships of the Achaeans are beached along the shores of a large U-shaped bay that opens into the Hellespont. See **[Map 1](https://chs.harvard.edu/CHS/article/display/3276.7-conflicting-claims-on-homer)** and **[Map 2](https://chs.harvard.edu/CHS/article/display/3276.7-conflicting-claims-on-homer)** at HPC 157 and 158 respectively. Such a bay no longer exists, because of long-term silting from the river Scamander, which emptied into the bay. In the second millennium BCE and even later, however, the bay was very much of a reality, as the maps show, and the visualization in the Homeric *Iliad* approximates such a topographical reality. This is not to say, however, that we should imagine the ships of the Achaeans as floating at anchor in the waters of such a bay: rather, the *Iliad* pictures the ships are beached along the shores of the bay, with their sterns facing inland and their prows facing out toward the waters. On this positioning, see also the comment on I.14.027â€“036. Exploring further the Iliadic visualization, we can see that the beached ship of Odysseus is located at the bottom of the U-shaped bay, at the south in the middle of the bayline, while the beached ships of Achilles and Ajax are located respectively at the upper left and the upper right tips of the U, at the northwest and northeast. To be highlighted here is a detail about the ship of Odysseus: the king Agamemnon is shown standing on the deck of this beached ship, which is said to be located *en messatÅi* â€˜in the middlemost spaceâ€™, I.08.223, and from here this over-king projects his voice of royal authority, shouting mightily to all the Achaeans stationed at their own ships, I.08.227. Correspondingly, all the Achaeans stationed at all the beached ships can hear the kingâ€™s voiceâ€”from the ship of Achilles at one extreme of the U-shaped bay all the way to the ship of Ajax at the other extreme, I.08.224â€“226 (HPC 160â€“161). Agamemnonâ€™s own beached ship, together with the ships of Diomedes and Nestor, is located near the ship of Odysseus, and it is in this â€˜middlemost spaceâ€™ of the U-shaped bayline that the central station of the Achaeans is visualized by the narrative, I.08.223. In the later comments at I.11.005â€“016, I.11.806â€“808, and I.14.027â€“036, there will be more to say about the locations of all these beached ships. To be highlighted already now, however, is the general reference to the *klisiai* or â€˜sheltersâ€™ here at I.08.220, which are the abodes of the heroes. Then at I.08.224 the same word *klisiai* refers specifically to the abodes of Achilles and Ajax, mentioned at I.08.224â€“225. The description here shows that the *klisiai* â€˜sheltersâ€™ of these two heroes are pointedly aligned with their beached ships. As for the ships beached at the middle of the bayline in the south, they mark a political and sacral centerpoint for the Achaeans. The evidence for the preceding formulation will be presented in the comment on I.11.806â€“808.

By blaming or insulting his fellow Achaeans for not daring to stand up to the onslaught of Hector, Agamemnon is goading them into action. His insulting words recall a scene that took place in their collective epic past, on the island of Lemnos, where the Achaeans were competitively boasting about the exploits they will perform in the future when they fight in the Trojan War. The idea of â€˜boastingâ€™ is conveyed by the noun *eukhÅlÄ“*, which is derived from *eukhesthai* â€˜declareâ€™. As we already saw at I.01.091, what is at stake when an Achaean hero boasts in the *Iliad* centers on the all-important question: who is the â€˜best of the Achaeansâ€™? The noun *eukhÅlai* â€˜boastingsâ€™ in the plural here at I.08.229 indicates a distributive action: the Achaeans were boasting not as a group but individually and competitively. The object of such competition and dispute would have been: to show who is the *aristos* â€˜bestâ€™ of them all. When Agamemnon says at I.08.229 â€˜we were saying that we were best [*aristoi*]â€™, the plural construction here is distributive in meaning: â€˜each one of us was saying that he was the best [*aristos*]â€™. We see in this scene of a past event at Lemnos an epic precedent for what is ongoing in the present time of the Trojan War as narrated in the *Iliad*. Just as there was a dispute at Lemnos, there is a dispute ongoing in the *Iliad* about that all-important question: who is the â€˜best of the Achaeansâ€™? A most relevant detail in the story about the dispute at Lemnos is the fact that the context for the quarreling that took place at that time over the same question, who is the â€˜best of the Achaeansâ€™, was a feast where meat was being distributed, I.08.231. So the setting for the quarrel was an event that is elsewhere called a *dais*, to be defined as â€˜feast, division of portions (of meat); sacrificeâ€™ in Homeric diction. As we saw in the comment for I.01.423â€“425, a *dais* is a feast where meat is distributed, and this meat comes from the sacrifice of a sacrificial animal. Thus the act of sacrifice converts the feast of humans into a notional feast of the gods. This notion, â€˜feast of the godsâ€™, is made explicit in the â€œmicro-Iliadâ€ of O.8.072â€“083, which is the First Song of Demodokos. At O.08.076, the setting is described this way: Î¸Îµá¿¶Î½ á¼Î½ Î´Î±Î¹Ï„á½¶ Î¸Î±Î»ÎµÎ¯á¿ƒ â€˜at a sumptuous feast [*dais*] of the godsâ€™. So, what is happening at this feast? There is a dispute going on (Î´Î·ÏÎ¯ÏƒÎ±Î½Ï„Î¿ at ÎŸ.08.076), and the dispute is called a *neikos* â€˜quarrelâ€™ at O.08.075. The disputants are Odysseus and Achilles, who are described at O.08.078 as â€˜the best of the Achaeansâ€™. In terms of such a dispute in the context of a feast, each one of the two heroes would be claiming to be the â€˜best of the Achaeansâ€™. Similarly in the context of the feast at Lemnos as narrated by Agamemnon, each one of the heroes attending would be making such a claim.

@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001:9.1-9.3

The beginning of Rhapsody 9 picks up where Rhapsody 8 ended. There is a brief reference at I.09.001 to the ending of Rhapsody 8. Then, in the rest of the verse at I.09.001 and continuing into I.09.002â€“003 there is a transition into the narrative as it now resumes. A fitting term for this sort of transition is *rhapsodic sequencing*. Here as elsewhere, the transition of the narrative from one rhapsody to the next shows that each one of the 24 rhapsodies of the *Iliad*â€”and each one of the 24 rhapsodies of the *Odyssey*â€”is a distinct unit of performance. In the classical period of Athens, as we see in Platoâ€™s *Ion*, professional performers of Homeric rhapsodies were known as *rhapsÅidoi* â€˜rhapsodesâ€™. The term *rhapsÅidiÄ*, translated in this comment as â€˜rhapsodyâ€™, originates from the traditions of *rhapsÅidoi* â€˜rhapsodesâ€™ who performed poetry in competitive relay with other rhapsodes. Accordingly, the *rhapsÅidiai* â€˜rhapsodiesâ€™ of Homeric poetry can be seen as units of relay performance.

The Master Narrator now approaches what can surely be seen as the highest point so far in the narrative arc of the Homeric *Iliad*. Achilles has not spoken since Rhapsody 1. Now, in Rhapsody 9, he will speak again. And what he says will define what can and cannot happen in the rest of the *Iliad*.

And the relatively young age of Diomedes is likewise noted in the *Iliad*. In another battle scene, at I.14.109â€“114, while addressing his fellow warriors, Diomedes boasts that â€˜I am the youngest among youâ€™ (Î½ÎµÏÏ„Î±Ï„ÏŒÏ‚ Îµá¼°Î¼Î¹ Î¼ÎµÎ¸â€™ á½‘Î¼á¿–Î½), I.14.112. So, it may be that Diomedes is even younger than Antilokhos, but that is not the point. Rather, the point is that Antilokhos and Diomedes are comparably young. Nestor himself highlights the youth of Antilokhos when he addresses him on a later occasion, I.23.306. In view of all these other Homeric references, Nestorâ€™s remark at I.09.057â€“058 about Diomedes as comparable in age to Antilokhos can be seen as an evocation of an epic moment that is awaiting Nestor in the future. At that future moment, Antilokhos, his own young son, will try to save the old hero when Nestor gets entangled in his chariot and is about to be attacked and killed by the chariot fighter Memnon. Antilokhos will succeed in saving Nestor, but it is the young son and not the old father who will now get killed by Memnon. This epic moment, which is in the future for the *Iliad*, is evidently narrated in a part of the epic Cycle, the *Aithiopis*, attributed to Arctinus of Miletus, as we read in the plot-summary of Proclus p. 106 lines 4â€“6 (ed. Allen 1912). On the *epic Cycle*, see the inventory of Words and Ideas. There is also a reference to this same epic moment in a song of Pindar, *Pythian* 6.28â€“42. These nonâ€“Iliadic passages have already been cited in the anchor comment on the relevant Iliadic passage, Î™.08.076â€“117. In that passage, which is already in the epic past from the standpoint of the current Iliadic passage taken from I.09.057â€“058, Diomedes was acting as a stand-in for Antilokhos, performing in the epic past a task that mirrors the task that will be undertaken by Antilokhos in the epic future. That task was to save Nestor from his entanglement in his chariot. Diomedes saved the life of Nestor, and Nestor knows it when he now compares young Diomedes to his own young son, I.09.057â€“058. As for Antilokhos, he too will save the life of Nestor, but, unlike Diomedes, he will lose his own life in performing this same task in the future, which is, to save Nestor from another entanglement. And of course Nestor does not yet know it. So, there is an irony in the remark made by the old hero here in comparing young Diomedes to young Antilokhos, though of course the character of Nestor did not intend such an irony. The intentionality, rather, is to be found in the poetics of evocation.

@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001:9.128-9.131
:citation_urn: urn:cts:CHS:Commentaries.AHCIP:Iliad.9.128-9.131.xdB72TX

Among the prizes that Agamemnon at I.09.128â€“131 offers as compensation to Achilles are seven captive Aeolian women who were captured by Achilles when he conquered the Aeolian island of Lesbos. The story about these women as it is told here is then retold at I.09.270â€“272. The significance of the Aeolian identification of these women will be analyzed in the anchor comment that follows. The focus in the present comment, by contrast, is on the moral problems that are raised in the story about the actual capture of these womenâ€”and of other women in the *Iliad* who suffer the same fate of captivity. Two prominent examples are Briseis and Chryseis, captured by Achilles when he conquered the cities of Lyrnessos and ThÄ“bÄ“ respectively, as noted in the anchor comment at I.02.689â€“694. All these womenâ€”the seven unnamed ones and the two named onesâ€”evidently became the common property of the Achaeans after being captured by Achilles, and it appears that Agamemnon as the Achaean over-king originally had a say, ostensibly by way of public deliberation with the rest of the Achaeans, in deciding which woman was allotted as a war-prize to which Achaean man. Even though all these women were captured by Achilles alone, they were thereafter to be distributed as war-prizes among the Achaean men as a group. In terms of this reconstruction of the story as outlined here, the role of Agamemnon in having a say about the awarding of these captive women as war-prizes is morally problematic. Likewise problematic is this over-kingâ€™s role in the original awarding of the captive woman Briseis, with the approval of the Achaeans, as a war-prize to Achillesâ€”and in the parallel awarding of the captive woman Chryseis to himself. Moreover, the seizing of Briseis by Agamemnon after his loss of Chryseis is even more problematic. Here, then, is the overriding question to be asked about the treatment of all these women as war-prizes: is Agamemnon entitled to have a say in deciding which Achaean man will have sex with which woman? And the question can be broadened: are the Achaeans as a group entitled to make such decisions? Such a broader question extends also to Achilles.

@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001:9.128-9.131
:citation_urn: urn:cts:CHS:Commentaries.AHCIP:Iliad.9.128-9.131.EPgZ5v4
:created_at: 2020-03-12T16:44:25.575Z
:updated_at: 2020-03-12T16:44:25.575Z

The story that is being told here at I.09.128â€“131 and retold at I.09.270â€“272 centers on one single stunning event: Achilles captured the entire island of Lesbos. By implication, this island became Aeolian precisely because it was captured by the principal hero of the Aeolians. The vastness of this story is even broader in scope, since we can see in the *Iliad* occasional references to other such conquests accomplished by Achilles. Most prominent are the Iliadic references to his capturing of two cities located on the Aeolian mainland of Asia Minor: they are Lyrnessos and ThÄ“bÄ“. In the *Iliad*, the conquest of Lyrnessos by Achilles and his capturing of Briseis are mentioned for the first time at I.02.690â€“691. What then follows at I.02.691 is a mention of his conquering the walled city of ThÄ“bÄ“ as well. ThÄ“bÄ“ is mentioned already at I.01.366: it was there that Achilles captured another woman, Chryseis, when he conquered that city, I.01.366â€“369. For background on Briseis and on Chryseis, I again strongly recommend the work of DuÃ© 2002 and 2006, listed in the Bibliography. Another native of ThÄ“bÄ“ was Andromache, who had been married off to Hector at Troy before the beginning of the Trojan War: she was taken captive only later, after Troy was captured, and she was then allotted as a war-prize to the son of Achilles, Neoptolemos: the story was told in an epic that was part of the epic Cycle and was known as the *Iliou Persis* â€˜Destruction of Ilionâ€™, attributed to Arctinus of Miletus, plot summary by Proclus p. 108 line 9 (ed. Allen 1912). That said, I now elaborate further on the argument initiated in the anchor comment at I.02.689â€“694: the conquests of these territories by Achilles, especially his capture of Lesbos, can be interpreted as a charter myth that aetiologizes a prehistoric or even non-historical â€œcolonizationâ€ of east Aeolis, as it were, by west Aeolian migrants from Thessaly, situated in the European mainland, which was the reputed birthplace of Achilles. See Nagy 2011b:171â€“173. In using the term â€œeast Aeolisâ€ here, I am referring to the islands of Lesbos and Tenedos, together with the facing mainland of northern Asia Minor. The â€œcolonizationâ€ of this area has conventionally been described as the â€œAeolian Migration,â€ and the term â€˜migrationâ€™ here matches neatly the appropriate Greek word, *apoikiÄ* as used in Strabo 9.2.3 C401 and elsewhere (see Nagy 2011b:161). The reference at I.09.129 to the captive women from Lesbos can be correlated with the poetic traditions of Lesbos as later attested in the songs of Sappho and Alcaeus, both dated around 600 BCE. These poetic traditions, which are decidedly Aeolian, derive not only from the island of Lesbos but also from the island of Tenedos and from the mainland of northern Asia Minor facing these two islands. See HPC 184â€“185. Traces of these Aeolian poetic traditions can be seen in the Iliadic references to such figures as Briseis, Chryseis, Andromache, and the seven unnamed captive women from Lesbos. All these figures derive from Aeolian poetic traditions, and the same can be said about the figure of Achilles himself: in terms of his poetic heritage, he is Achilles the Aeolian. See Nagy 2011b:171â€“172. But there is an important difference to be highlighted here: Achilles is an Aeolian from European Thessaly, while the captive women are Aeolians from Asia Minor and from the offshore islands of Lesbos and Tenedos (on the captive woman Hekamede from Tenedos, see the anchor comment at I.11.624â€“627). In the Ionian poetic traditions of epic as exemplified by Homeric poetry, we can track the early influence of corresponding Aeolian poetic traditions as exemplified at a later period, around 600 BCE, by the songmaking of Sappho and Alcaeus. See also anchor comment at I.02.689â€“694 on: Aeolian women in the *Iliad*, part 1 and anchor comment at I.11.624â€“627 on: Aeolian women in the *Iliad*, part 3.

@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001:9.130
:citation_urn: urn:cts:CHS:Commentaries.AHCIP:Iliad.9.130.bECuBss

The description of the women from Lesbos as victorious over other women in their beauty can be interpreted as a reference to a local tradition at Lesbos known as the *Kallisteia*, which was a kind of ritualized beauty contest for girls and for women. The scholia D for the *Iliad* give details, with specific reference to I.09.130: this beauty contest was a seasonally recurring event that took place in a federal space that was shared by five cities on the island of Lesbos, and this space was sacred to the goddess HÄ“rÄ. See Nagy 2015Â§Â§135â€“159. There are occasional references to this space in what remains of the songs of Sappho and Alcaeus (again, Nagy 2015). Also, as we see at I.09.128, the beauty of the women of Lesbos is matched by the beauty of their handiwork, which externalizes their aristocratic charisma. Such handiwork, as we will see in another comment, comes to life in the skillfulness displayed by women in practicing their art of pattern-weaving: a prime example is Andromache the Aeolian, described at Î™.22.440â€“441 in the act of pattern-weaving. There and elsewhere, the craft of pattern-weaving by Aeolian women is linked with the power of the craft of Homeric poetry to make contact with the Bronze Age. See MoM 2Â§Â§69â€“81.

@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001:9.182-9.198
:citation_urn: urn:cts:CHS:Commentaries.AHCIP:Iliad.9.182-9.198.mc66Dm3
:created_at: 2020-03-12T16:44:26.089Z
:updated_at: 2020-03-12T16:44:26.089Z

As the three ambassadors and the two heralds proceed toward the shelter of Achilles, a series of dual forms is activated in the narrative, starting already with the very first verse and continuing from there: 182, 183, 185, 192, 196, 197, 198. The intervening plurals as at 186 are negligible, since plurals can normally substitute for duals in Homeric diction. But duals cannot substitute for plurals. So, the problem is, who are the referents in these contexts where the dual form is used? One way to approach the problem is to follow through on the formulation of Nestor, who had said that Phoenix must lead the embassy, I.09.168, followed by Ajax and then by Odysseus, I.09.169. See the comment on I.09.167â€“170. But then, when the group reaches the shelter of Achilles, it is said explicitly that Odysseus now takes the lead, I.09.192. Further, when Ajax signals to Phoenix at I.09.223, it is Odysseus who picks up the signal instead, as indicated by the verb *noeÃ®n* â€˜take note (of), noticeâ€™ (see further the comment on I.09.223), and now it will be Odysseus and not Phoenix who delivers the first of the three speeches. At I.09.224, Odysseus fills a goblet with wine and toasts Achillesâ€”a gesture that may have seemed more appropriate for Achilles to perform as the host, not for Odysseus as the guest. For Odysseus to violate the etiquette is not to violate the traditions of myth, however, in that *it is traditional for the figure of Odysseus to violate rules of etiquette*. At O.08.475â€“476, to cite another example, Odysseus seems to be behaving like a host in a situation where he is really the guest. For more on this point, see HQ 142. In any case, right after pouring the wine and toasting Achilles, Odysseus starts at I.09.225 to deliver the first of the three speeches addressed by the three ambassadors to Achilles. Only after this speech of Odysseus, I.09.225â€“306, and after the reply of Achilles to that speech, I.09.308â€“429, will Phoenix get a chance to give his own speech, I.09.434â€“605â€”even though Nestor had intended for Phoenix to be the first speaker. So, returning to I.09.192, where Odysseus already takes the lead away from Phoenix, we can view this point in the narrative as the marker of a transition: before this point, the dual forms could refer to Ajax and Odysseus, as led by Phoenix, but then, after this point, the dual forms could refer to Phoenix and Ajax, as led by Odysseus. Alternatively the dual forms in these verses could have an elliptic function, where a singular X is paired with a group Y. This way, the dual still refers to a pair, even though the second part of the pair is a group.

As Odysseus warns, I.09.249, Achilles will suffer *akhos* â€˜griefâ€™ in some unforeseeable way if he does not help the Achaeans right now. And there will be no *akos* â€˜remedyâ€™ for the pain of this grief, I.09.250. The warning will come true, since the future death of Patroklos will turn Achilles into *a man of constant sorrow*. See especially the comment on I.18.015â€“073; also the comment on I.23.046â€“047. Of special interest here at I.09.249â€“250 is the morphological parallelism of *akhos* â€˜griefâ€™ at I.09.249 with *akos* â€˜remedyâ€™ at I.09.250. Another morphological parallel for *akos* â€˜remedyâ€™ is the synonym *althos* â€˜remedyâ€™. Whereas *akos* and *althos* are synonyms, they are both antonyms of *akhos*, and the morphological parallelism of all three words serves to highlight the semantic contrast of *akhos* on one side with *akos* and *althos* on the other side. The morphological parallelism extends to names derived from the antonyms *althos* and *akhos*, since *althos* â€˜remedyâ€™ is to *AlthaiÄ* as *akhos* â€˜griefâ€™ is to *AkhaiÄ* (see BA 88).

@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001:9.270-9.272
:citation_urn: urn:cts:CHS:Commentaries.AHCIP:Iliad.9.270-9.272.vDQHEoQ

The story that is being told here at I.09.128â€“131 and retold at I.09.270â€“272 centers on one single stunning event: Achilles captured the entire island of Lesbos. By implication, this island became Aeolian precisely because it was captured by the principal hero of the Aeolians. The vastness of this story is even broader in scope, since we can see in the *Iliad* occasional references to other such conquests accomplished by Achilles. Most prominent are the Iliadic references to his capturing of two cities located on the Aeolian mainland of Asia Minor: they are Lyrnessos and ThÄ“bÄ“. In the *Iliad*, the conquest of Lyrnessos by Achilles and his capturing of Briseis are mentioned for the first time at I.02.690â€“691. What then follows at I.02.691 is a mention of his conquering the walled city of ThÄ“bÄ“ as well. ThÄ“bÄ“ is mentioned already at I.01.366: it was there that Achilles captured another woman, Chryseis, when he conquered that city, I.01.366â€“369. For background on Briseis and on Chryseis, I again strongly recommend the work of DuÃ© 2002 and 2006, listed in the Bibliography. Another native of ThÄ“bÄ“ was Andromache, who had been married off to Hector at Troy before the beginning of the Trojan War: she was taken captive only later, after Troy was captured, and she was then allotted as a war-prize to the son of Achilles, Neoptolemos: the story was told in an epic that was part of the epic Cycle and was known as the *Iliou Persis* â€˜Destruction of Ilionâ€™, attributed to Arctinus of Miletus, plot summary by Proclus p. 108 line 9 (ed. Allen 1912). That said, I now elaborate further on the argument initiated in the anchor comment at I.02.689â€“694: the conquests of these territories by Achilles, especially his capture of Lesbos, can be interpreted as a charter myth that aetiologizes a prehistoric or even non-historical â€œcolonizationâ€ of east Aeolis, as it were, by west Aeolian migrants from Thessaly, situated in the European mainland, which was the reputed birthplace of Achilles. See Nagy 2011b:171â€“173. In using the term â€œeast Aeolisâ€ here, I am referring to the islands of Lesbos and Tenedos, together with the facing mainland of northern Asia Minor. The â€œcolonizationâ€ of this area has conventionally been described as the â€œAeolian Migration,â€ and the term â€˜migrationâ€™ here matches neatly the appropriate Greek word, *apoikiÄ* as used in Strabo 9.2.3 C401 and elsewhere (see Nagy 2011b:161). The reference at I.09.129 to the captive women from Lesbos can be correlated with the poetic traditions of Lesbos as later attested in the songs of Sappho and Alcaeus, both dated around 600 BCE. These poetic traditions, which are decidedly Aeolian, derive not only from the island of Lesbos but also from the island of Tenedos and from the mainland of northern Asia Minor facing these two islands. See HPC 184â€“185. Traces of these Aeolian poetic traditions can be seen in the Iliadic references to such figures as Briseis, Chryseis, Andromache, and the seven unnamed captive women from Lesbos. All these figures derive from Aeolian poetic traditions, and the same can be said about the figure of Achilles himself: in terms of his poetic heritage, he is Achilles the Aeolian. See Nagy 2011b:171â€“172. But there is an important difference to be highlighted here: Achilles is an Aeolian from European Thessaly, while the captive women are Aeolians from Asia Minor and from the offshore islands of Lesbos and Tenedos (on the captive woman Hekamede from Tenedos, see the anchor comment at I.11.624â€“627). In the Ionian poetic traditions of epic as exemplified by Homeric poetry, we can track the early influence of corresponding Aeolian poetic traditions as exemplified at a later period, around 600 BCE, by the songmaking of Sappho and Alcaeus. See also anchor comment at I.02.689â€“694 on: Aeolian women in the *Iliad*, part 1 and anchor comment at I.11.624â€“627 on: Aeolian women in the *Iliad*, part 3.

@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001:9.270-9.272
:citation_urn: urn:cts:CHS:Commentaries.AHCIP:Iliad.9.270-9.272.hqT4zWF
:created_at: 2020-03-12T16:44:26.859Z
:updated_at: 2020-03-12T16:44:26.859Z

Among the prizes that Agamemnon at I.09.128â€“131 offers as compensation to Achilles are seven captive Aeolian women who were captured by Achilles when he conquered the Aeolian island of Lesbos. The story about these women as it is told here is then retold at I.09.270â€“272. The significance of the Aeolian identification of these women will be analyzed in the anchor comment that follows. The focus in the present comment, by contrast, is on the moral problems that are raised in the story about the actual capture of these womenâ€”and of other women in the *Iliad* who suffer the same fate of captivity. Two prominent examples are Briseis and Chryseis, captured by Achilles when he conquered the cities of Lyrnessos and ThÄ“bÄ“ respectively, as noted in the anchor comment at I.02.689â€“694. All these womenâ€”the seven unnamed ones and the two named onesâ€”evidently became the common property of the Achaeans after being captured by Achilles, and it appears that Agamemnon as the Achaean over-king originally had a say, ostensibly by way of public deliberation with the rest of the Achaeans, in deciding which woman was allotted as a war-prize to which Achaean man. Even though all these women were captured by Achilles alone, they were thereafter to be distributed as war-prizes among the Achaean men as a group. In terms of this reconstruction of the story as outlined here, the role of Agamemnon in having a say about the awarding of these captive women as war-prizes is morally problematic. Likewise problematic is this over-kingâ€™s role in the original awarding of the captive woman Briseis, with the approval of the Achaeans, as a war-prize to Achillesâ€”and in the parallel awarding of the captive woman Chryseis to himself. Moreover, the seizing of Briseis by Agamemnon after his loss of Chryseis is even more problematic. Here, then, is the overriding question to be asked about the treatment of all these women as war-prizes: is Agamemnon entitled to have a say in deciding which Achaean man will have sex with which woman? And the question can be broadened: are the Achaeans as a group entitled to make such decisions? Such a broader question extends also to Achilles.

I suggest that the story embedded here about 11 cities that Achilles conquers on foot, I.09.329â€“333, may be an indirect reference to the 12 cities of the Aeolian Dodecapolis minus Smyrna, which was lost to the Ionians. For details about these 12 cities, see the inventory of Words and Ideas under *Aeolian Dodecapolis*. By contrast, Achilles conquers 12 other cities not on foot but *sun nÄ“usi* (Ïƒá½ºÎ½ Î½Î·Ï…Ïƒá½·) â€˜by way of shipsâ€™, I.09.328. Similarly at I.06.640â€“642, HÄ“raklÄ“s had earlier conquered Troy itself *hex oiÄ“is sun nÄ“usi* (á¼“Î¾ Î¿á¼´á¿ƒÏ‚ Ïƒá½ºÎ½ Î½Î·Ï…Ïƒá½·) â€˜by way of merely six shipsâ€™, I.06.641. The analogous deed of HÄ“raklÄ“s here leads me to think that Achilles too was conquering the 12 cities in the vicinity of Troy, whereas the other 11 cities would have been situated further south on the mainland of Asia Minor, that is, in the territory of the ancient Aeolian Dodecapolis. Herodotus 1.149.1 lists the cities of the Aeolian Dodecapolis, and one of them happens to be Killa. I think that this Killa is the same place that is mentioned twice in the *Iliad*, I.01.038 and I.01.452, in the context of Aeolian places that are specially sacred to Apollo. The two other places mentioned both times in those passages at I.01.038â€“039 and at I.01.451â€“452 are Chrysa and Tenedos. It has been argued that the Homeric Killa cannot be the same place as the Killa mentioned by Herodotus (Leaf 1923:310), but such arguments are based on the assumption that Homeric Killa was near Lyrnessos and ThÄ“bÄ“, two other places said to be conquered by Achilles. Herodotus 1.151.1 notes that the Aeolian cities on the mainland of northern Asia Minor in the region of Mount Idaâ€”that is, in the general area of ancient Troyâ€”were grouped separately from the Aeolian Dodecapolis, but he does not list those cities by name. The reason, I suspect, is that any federation of cities situated in this area would have been already severely disrupted by the Athenian empire in the fifth century BCE, that is, in the era of Herodotus, and, earlier, by the domination of this area by the Aeolian city of Mytilene in the seventh and the sixth centuries BCE. In that era, this city on the island of Lesbos was a major rival of Athens in seeking to possess the sacred real estate, so to speak, of ancient Troy and its environs. See Point 7 in the anchor comment that follows immediately below.

There are ten points in this anchor comment, epitomized mostly from HPC 131â€“146:

Point 1. Our point of departure is New Ilion, which in the historical period was an Aeolian city built over the ruins of the old Troy of the Trojan War as narrated in the epic that we know as the Homeric *Iliad*. Archaeologists have verified that HisarlÄ±k, which is the Turkish name for the site of New Ilion, was in fact the same place as the site of old Troy, which was also known in the ancient world as Ilion. [HPC 131]

Point 2. After a major destruction of the citadel at old Troy sometime around the beginning of the 12th century BCE, which marks the end of a phase that archaeologists recognize as Troy VIIa, the importance of the site was radically diminished, and things stayed that way through the phase known as Troy VIIb, lasting into the 10th century BCE. After Troy VIIb comes Troy VIII, which marks a â€œGreek eraâ€ extending all the way to the so-called â€œRoman eraâ€ that is Troy IX. In the earliest phase of Troy VIII, from the 10th to the mid-7th century BCE, a small population was occupying the area of the citadel, and, on the western side of the citadel wall, they left behind some archaeological remains of a â€œplace of memoryâ€ that must have commemorated in some way the epic traditions of the Trojan War (Aslan and Rose 2013:11). At a later phase of Troy VIII, in the mid-7th century BCE, there was a destruction, to be followed in the late 7th century by a reoccupation. From this time onward, in the latest phase of Troy VIII, we see the beginnings of the historical period. Now the old Troy is on its way to becoming the new Troy, that is, New Ilion. [HPC 131.]

Point 3. As in modern times, the old Troy of New Ilion was sought out in antiquity, most prominently by rulers striving to link themselves with the heroes who fought in the Trojan War of the epic past. In 480 BCE, as we read in Herodotus 7.43.2, Xerxes the king of the Persian Empire traveled to New Ilion and made sacrifice there to the goddess Athena, and his magi made libations to the *hÄ“rÅes* â€˜heroesâ€™ who were entombed in the environs. Over a century later, Alexander the Great likewise sacrificed to Athena in New Ilion (Strabo 13.1.26 C593; Arrian *Anabasis* 1.11.7). [HPC 131â€“132.]

Point 4. I highlight the term used by Herodotus here at 7.43.2 in referring to the goddess Athena as worshipped in her sacred space at New Ilion: she is *hÄ“ Ilias*, meaning something like â€˜she who is in Ilionâ€™. But the name can also be interpreted to mean â€˜she who is in the Iliadâ€™, in the sense that *Ilias* as an â€˜Iliadâ€™ means simply â€˜the song about Ilionâ€™. [HPC 126.]

Point 5. Elsewhere, at 5.122.2, Herodotus uses the same expression *hÄ“ Ilias* in referring to *the territory of Ilion as inhabited by Aeolians*. The context is this: a Persian general was redeploying his forces at the time of the Ionian Revolt, ongoing in the first decade of the 5th century BCE, and he was moving his troops westward in the direction of the Hellespont (á¼Ï€á½¶ Ï„á½¸Î½ á¼™Î»Î»Î®ÏƒÏ€Î¿Î½Ï„Î¿Î½). Then, along the way to the Hellespont, â€˜he captured all the Aeolians who inhabit the territory of Ilion [*hÄ“ Ilias*]â€™ (ÎºÎ±á½¶ Îµá¼·Î»Îµ Î¼á½²Î½ Î‘á¼°Î¿Î»Î­Î±Ï‚ Ï€Î¬Î½Ï„Î±Ï‚ á½…ÏƒÎ¿Î¹ Ï„á½´Î½ á¼¸Î»Î¹Î¬Î´Î± Î½Î­Î¼Î¿Î½Ï„Î±Î¹). This detail from Herodotus concerning *hÄ“ Ilias* as â€˜the territory of Ilionâ€™ is a most valuable piece of evidence showing that New Ilion was at this time inhabited by *AioleÃ®s* â€˜Aeoliansâ€™. I should add that there is a plethora of further evidence showing the Aeolian identity of New Ilion in the era of Troy VIII. [HPC 142â€“146.]

Point 6. But now we must confront a big complication. This New Ilion was not the only â€˜new Ilionâ€™. As early as the late seventh century BCE, a rival â€˜new Ilionâ€™ emerged, and its occupants claimed that their site replaced the real Troy of olden days. This alternative New Ilion was located not far from the old Troy, but it was a different site. The inherited name of the site was Sigeion, and it was situated on a promontory at Kum Kale, overlooking the entrance to the narrows of the Hellespont. Archaeologists have securely identified the site at Cape YeniÅŸehir as Sigeion. [HPC 143; see the map at [HPC 158](https://chs.harvard.edu/CHS/article/display/3276.7-conflicting-claims-on-homer).]

Point 7. Like the New Ilion that was built over the old Troy, the site of Sigeion used to be occupied by Aeolians. Also, for some time in the seventh century BCE, Sigeion had been dominated by one particular sub-group of Aeolians, namely, the elites of Mytilene, which was then the most powerful city in Lesbos, an Aeolian island situated due west across the sea from the Aeolian mainland of northern Asia Minor. As we read in Strabo 13.1.38 C599, the Mytilenaeans under the leadership of one Archeanax built the walls of the citadel of Sigeion from the stones of the ruined walls of the ancient citadel of Troy. Strabo thinks that this important piece of information validates arguments made in the second century BCE by the antiquarian Demetrius of Scepsis, who denied any continuity between the old Ilion and the city of New Ilion as it existed in his own day, claiming that there was no trace left of the old Ilionâ€”and that the site of this old city was not New Ilion but rather a village located some 30 stadium-lengths to the southeast, in the territory of Scepsis. In terms of the theory posited by Demetrius, all the stones of the old Ilion had been used up in the process of building the walls of other cities like Sigeion. But we have already seen at Point 2 that the stones of the old Ilion were in fact still very much in evidence throughout the phase known as Troy VIII, and so the theory of Demetrius is invalidated. See also the comment on I.07.433â€“465 on the myth about the building of the Trojan Wall by Poseidon and Apollo for Laomedon, who had been king of Troy before Priam, I.07.452â€“453. Still, the information reported by Demetrius and transmitted by Strabo about the re-using of stones from old Troy for the building of new Troys retains its full value. A shining example of another such new Troy was the Aeolian city of Neon Teikhos â€˜New Wallâ€™, which belonged to a confederation of twelve Aeolian cities situated on the mainland of Asia Minor and commonly known as the Aeolian Dodecapolis (Herodotus 1.149.1 lists them all). [HPC 145â€“146. About Neon Teikhos, see also HPC 180.]

Point 8. Unlike New Ilion, which remained an Aeolian site, the city of Sigeion underwent a drastic change in identity, and this happened already in the late seventh century BCE. Somewhere around that time, control of Sigeion was seized by the Ionian city of Athens and taken away from the Aeolian city of Mytilene-in-Lesbos, which had dominated Sigeion earlier, as we saw at Point 7. I cannot go into details here about this drastic change, but I will at least highlight the fact that Sigeion is pictured as already belonging to Athens in the poetry of Alcaeus, who can be dated to the late seventh century BCE. Herodotus notes that Alcaeus himself says in his own poetry that his armor was captured from him by the Athenians in a battle against the Mytilenaeans, and that it was displayed by the enemy at the *Athá¸—naion* â€˜sacred space of Athenaâ€™ in Sigeion. Here is the way Herodotus says it at 5.95.1: â€˜the Athenians have his [= Alcaeusâ€™] armor and they have hung it up for display at the space of Athena [*Athá¸—naion*] in Sigeionâ€™ (Ï„á½° Î´á½³ Î¿á¼± á½…Ï€Î»Î± á¼´ÏƒÏ‡Î¿Ï…ÏƒÎ¹ á¼ˆÎ¸Î·Î½Î±á¿–Î¿Î¹ ÎºÎ±á½· ÏƒÏ†ÎµÎ± á¼€Î½ÎµÎºÏá½³Î¼Î±ÏƒÎ±Î½ Ï€Ïá½¸Ï‚ Ï„á½¸ á¼ˆÎ¸á½µÎ½Î±Î¹Î¿Î½ Ï„á½¸ á¼Î½ Î£Î¹Î³Îµá½·á¿³). Strabo quotes the words of Alcaeus telling about the captured armor, and these words actually give the name of Athenaâ€™s sacred space as *Glauká¹“pion* (Alcaeus F 401B via Strabo 13.1.37 C600). This same name *Glauká¹“pion*, derived from the sacred epithet of Athena *glaukÃ´pis* â€˜having the looks of the owlâ€™, is attested in Athens as well. There it applies to the sacred space of Athena Nike at the southwest corner of the acropolis (Callimachus F 238.11), and this space, like the *Glauká¹“pion* in Sigeion, can be dated at around 600 BCE. On the protracted war between the Athenians and the Mytilenaeans over the possession of Sigeion, I cite the primary sources here: Herodotus (5.94â€“95), Strabo (13.1.38â€“39 C599â€“600), and Diogenes Laertius (1.74); a most admirable secondary source is Aloni 1986. [HPC 142â€“146.]

Point 9. Just as Athena had a sacred space in the new Ilion of Sigeion, so also she had her own sacred space in the New Ilion built on top of the old Troy, where as we have already read in Herodotus 7.43.2 the goddess was worshipped as *hÄ“ Ilias*, meaning not only â€˜she who is in Ilionâ€™ but also â€˜she who is in the Iliadâ€™. As noted at Point 4, such an â€˜Iliadâ€™ was not the Homeric *Iliad* that we have but instead â€˜the song about Ilionâ€™ as it was known thenâ€”and as it was known even earlier when the occupants of Troy VIII were already venerating a â€œplace of memoryâ€ commemorating the epic traditions of the Trojan War, as we saw at Point 2. [HPC 131.]

Point 10. There may be some uncertainties about positively identifying an earlier version of â€˜Iliadicâ€™ Athenaâ€”*hÄ“ Ilias*â€”as the goddess who presided over the â€œplace of memoryâ€ in the early phases of Troy VIII, but we can be quite certain about the actual linking of the old Troy with epic traditions about an old Troy. And here again the same expression *hÄ“ Ilias* applies: at Point 5, we already saw that Herodotus 5.122.2 says *hÄ“ Ilias* in referring to the territory of Ilion as inhabited by *AioleÃ®s* â€˜Aeoliansâ€™. But now we will see that Herodotus also uses the same expression *hÄ“ Ilias* in a context where he refers to a territory belonging not only to Ilion but also to the Iliadic tradition of poetry. The context is this: Herodotus is describing a scene where representatives of the cities of Mytilene and Athens, which have evidently already fought in many wars over the possession of Sigeion, are submitting their dispute to inter-state arbitration, and now the Aeolians of Mytilene are demanding that the Athenians give back to them the territory of Sigeion and its environs (Herodotus 5.94.2): â€˜You see, the Mytilenaeans and the Athenians had been waging war with each other for the longest time. One side [= the Mytilenaeans] operated out of the city [*polis*] of AkhÃ­lleion and the other side [= the Athenians], out of Sigeion. They [= the Mytilenaeans] were demanding the return of the territory [*khÅrÄ*], but the Athenians rejected the demand, trying to demonstrate by way of what they said that the Aeolians were no more entitled to the Iliadic territory [*hÄ“ Ilias khÅrÄ*] than were they [= the Athenians] and all the other Hellenes who had joined forces in avenging Menelaos for the abduction of Helenâ€™ (á¼Ï€Î¿Î»Î­Î¼ÎµÎ¿Î½ Î³á½°Ï á¼”Îº Ï„Îµ á¼ˆÏ‡Î¹Î»Î»Î·Î¯Î¿Ï… Ï€ÏŒÎ»Î¹Î¿Ï‚ á½ÏÎ¼ÏÎ¼ÎµÎ½Î¿Î¹ ÎºÎ±á½¶ Î£Î¹Î³ÎµÎ¯Î¿Ï… á¼Ï€á½¶ Ï‡ÏÏŒÎ½Î¿Î½ ÏƒÏ…Ï‡Î½á½¸Î½ ÎœÏ…Ï„Î¹Î»Î·Î½Î±á¿–Î¿Î¯ Ï„Îµ ÎºÎ±á½¶ á¼ˆÎ¸Î·Î½Î±á¿–Î¿Î¹, Î¿á¼± Î¼á½²Î½ á¼€Ï€Î±Î¹Ï„Î­Î¿Î½Ï„ÎµÏ‚ Ï„á½´Î½ Ï‡ÏÏÎ·Î½, á¼ˆÎ¸Î·Î½Î±á¿–Î¿Î¹ Î´á½² Î¿á½”Ï„Îµ ÏƒÏ…Î³Î³Î¹Î½Ï‰ÏƒÎºÏŒÎ¼ÎµÎ½Î¿Î¹ á¼€Ï€Î¿Î´ÎµÎ¹ÎºÎ½ÏÎ½Ï„ÎµÏ‚ Ï„Îµ Î»ÏŒÎ³á¿³ Î¿á½Î´á½²Î½ Î¼á¾¶Î»Î»Î¿Î½ Î‘á¼°Î¿Î»Îµá¿¦ÏƒÎ¹ Î¼ÎµÏ„Îµá½¸Î½ Ï„á¿†Ï‚ á¼¸Î»Î¹Î¬Î´Î¿Ï‚ Ï‡ÏÏÎ·Ï‚ á¼¢ Î¿á½ ÎºÎ±á½¶ ÏƒÏ†Î¯ÏƒÎ¹ ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ï„Î¿á¿–ÏƒÎ¹ á¼„Î»Î»Î¿Î¹ÏƒÎ¹, á½…ÏƒÎ¿Î¹ á¼™Î»Î»Î®Î½Ï‰Î½ ÏƒÏ…Î½ÎµÏ€ÏÎ®Î¾Î±Î½Ï„Î¿ ÎœÎµÎ½Î­Î»Îµá¿³ Ï„á½°Ï‚ á¼™Î»Î­Î½Î·Ï‚ á¼ÏÏ€Î±Î³Î¬Ï‚). As the wording of Herodotus indicates, the Aeolian city of Mytilene in Lesbos claimed to be representing all Aeolic-speaking Hellenes in claiming possession of the Iliadic territory of Sigeion in the Troad. By contrast, the city of Athens claimed to be representing all Hellenes who took part in the Trojan War. From the standpoint of both sides, then, the disputed territory is poetic as well as political. [HPC 145.]

By now the feelings of Achilles about the captive woman Briseis whom he had won and then lost as a war-prize have deepened and intensified. He says that he now loves her as if she were his wife. And he asks ironically: are Agamemnon and Menelaos the only Achaeans entitled to love their wives? And do they even love them? Whether or not they do, is the wife of Menelaos, Helen, really worth fighting for and even dying for?

Achilles in his speech here returns to something that Odysseus had said at I.09.241â€“243: how the Achaeans are afraid that Hectorâ€™s fire will reach their ships beached at the Hellespont, and that such a disaster would surely destroy them. Achilles now gives a biting response at I.09.347: let Agamemnon find a way to ward off the fire of Hector without the help of Achilles. The verb used here for the idea of finding a way, *phrazesthai* â€˜devise a planâ€™, is correlated with the noun *mÄ“tis* â€˜mind, intelligenceâ€™ in Homeric diction, as we see in the wording of Achilles at a later point, I.09.423. Since Odysseus is the primary exponent of *mÄ“tis* â€˜mind, intelligenceâ€™ in Homeric poetry, Achilles is in effect saying to him at I.09.347: let Agamemnon rely on your *mÄ“tis*, Odysseus, since he cannot any longer rely on my *biÄ“* â€˜force, violence, strengthâ€™. Achilles is the primary exponent of *biÄ“* â€˜force, violence, strengthâ€™ in Homeric poetry, just as Odysseus is the primary exponent of *mÄ“tis* â€˜mind, intelligenceâ€™. According to the scholia A for I.09.347, Aristarchus apparently thought that the passage we are now considering, I.09.346â€“352, was an allusion to another passage, O.08.072â€“083, which is about a quarrel that once took place between Achilles and Odysseus over one overriding question: will Troy be conquered by relying on the physical power of Achilles or on the mental power of Odysseus?

From the standpoint of its etymology, derived as it is from the verb *keirein* â€˜cut, sliceâ€™, the noun *ká¸—r* in the sense of a â€˜cutâ€™ or a â€˜sliceâ€™ or a â€˜portionâ€™ need not convey the negative idea of a â€˜fated deathâ€™. When a hero chooses between two alternative *kÃªres* or â€˜fatesâ€™, one of the two alternatives may be death but the other may be life. Thus when Achilles here speaks of two alternative *kÃªres* or â€˜fatesâ€™ that may await him, namely, either the *kleos* or â€˜gloryâ€™ that he will get if he dies young in the Trojan War or the *nostos* or â€˜homecomingâ€™ that will be his if he abandons that war, I.09.413, the second alternative is not really a â€˜fated deathâ€™ for Achilles as is the first alternative. Instead, a nostos â€˜homecomingâ€™ would give him life. But this life would be limited. It would last only until the heroâ€™s age runs out of time, just as the age of a plant will surely run out of time. Conversely, the kleos â€˜gloryâ€™ that the hero would get from dying young in the Trojan War would have an unlimited life of its own, because this *kleos* is conferred by poetry, and this poetry is held to be imperishable.

The *kleos* â€˜gloryâ€™ of the song that glorifies Achilles will be *aphthiton* â€˜imperishable, unwiltingâ€™, I.09.413. The analysis here will focus first on the general sense of â€˜imperishableâ€™ and then on the specific sense of â€˜unwiltingâ€™. The Greek combination of the adjective *Ã¡phthiton* â€˜imperishableâ€™ with the noun *klÃ©os* â€˜glory, fameâ€™ here at I.09.413 is parallel to the Indic combination of the adjective *Ã¡ká¹£ita*- â€˜imperishableâ€™ with the noun *Å›rÃ¡vas* â€˜glory, fameâ€™ at *Rig-Veda* 1.9.7 (full argumentation in GMP 123â€“126). From the standpoint of the formulaic system inherited by Homeric diction, the function of the adjective *Ã¡phthiton* in combination with the noun *klÃ©os* â€˜glory, fameâ€™ in the expression *kleos aphthiton estai* (ÎºÎ»Î­Î¿Ï‚ á¼„Ï†Î¸Î¹Ï„Î¿Î½ á¼”ÏƒÏ„Î±Î¹) at I.09.413 can be not only predicative, â€˜the glory will be imperishableâ€™, but also attributive, â€˜there will be a glory that is imperishableâ€™. An attributive syntax is indicated by the shorter expression *kleos estai* (ÎºÎ»Î­Î¿Ï‚ á¼”ÏƒÏ„Î±Î¹), as at I.07.458, meaning â€˜there will be a gloryâ€™. There is also the comparative evidence of the attributive syntax that we see at work in the cognate wording of Sappho Song 44.4, â€¦ *kleos aphthiton* (â€¦ ÎºÎ»Î­Î¿Ï‚ á¼„Ï†Î¸Î¹Ï„Î¿Î½) â€˜imperishable gloryâ€™ (line-final), and of Ibycus S151.47, â€¦ *kleos aphthiton hexeis* (â€¦ ÎºÎ»Î­Î¿Ï‚ á¼„Ï†Î¸Î¹Ï„Î¿Î½ á¼‘Î¾Îµá¿–Ï‚) â€˜you will have imperishable gloryâ€™ (line-final). On the other hand, the expression *kleos aphthiton estai* (ÎºÎ»Î­Î¿Ï‚ á¼„Ï†Î¸Î¹Ï„Î¿Î½ á¼”ÏƒÏ„Î±Î¹) at I.09.413 seems to be coefficient with the expression *kleos oupotâ€™ oleitai* (ÎºÎ»Î­Î¿Ï‚ Î¿á½”Ï€Î¿Ï„â€™ á½€Î»Îµá¿–Ï„Î±Î¹) as at I.02.325, â€˜the glory will never perishâ€™. See the comment on I.02.325. The syntax of *kleos oupotâ€™ oleitai* â€˜the glory will never perishâ€™, if we compare it to the syntax of *kleos aphthiton estai* at I.09.413, may point to a predicative use of the adjective *aphthiton*: â€˜the glory will be imperishableâ€™. It has been suggested that the expression *kleos oupotâ€™ oleitai* (ÎºÎ»Î­Î¿Ï‚ Î¿á½”Ï€Î¿Ï„â€™ á½€Î»Îµá¿–Ï„Î±Î¹) â€˜the glory will never perishâ€™ could have been used instead of *kleos aphthiton estai* (ÎºÎ»Î­Î¿Ï‚ á¼„Ï†Î¸Î¹Ï„Î¿Î½ á¼”ÏƒÏ„Î±Î¹) even at I.09.413 if it were not for the fact that the word *Åleto* (á½¤Î»ÎµÏ„Î¿) â€˜perishedâ€™ (the subject is *nostos* â€˜[safe] homecomingâ€™) is already used at the beginning of the same verse. It does not follow, however, that the wording *kleos aphthiton estai* (ÎºÎ»Î­Î¿Ï‚ á¼„Ï†Î¸Î¹Ï„Î¿Î½ á¼”ÏƒÏ„Î±Î¹) instead of *kleos oupotâ€™ oleitai* (ÎºÎ»Î­Î¿Ï‚ Î¿á½”Ï€Î¿Ï„â€™ á½€Î»Îµá¿–Ï„Î±Î¹) at I.09.413 must be some kind of a reactive innovation: on the contrary, this wording can be an archaism that survives precisely for the stylistic purpose of avoiding an awkward duplication of wording in the same verse. As a general approach to poetics, I suggest that allowance should regularly be made for the possibility that older forms can be activated in situations where a more innovative equivalent form might create a poetically awkward side-effect (GMP 122â€“123). That said, my focus of analysis now shifts from the general sense of the adjective *aphthito*- as â€˜imperishableâ€™ to its specific sense as â€˜unwiltingâ€™. This sense has already been noted in the comments on I.01.155, I.02.046, I.02.325. Unlike a plant that runs out of time, the *kleos* of poetic â€˜gloryâ€™ is like an imperishable flower that will never wilt, never lose its vibrant color and aroma. Accordingly, the *kleos aphthiton* of Achilles will be like an unwilting flower. And the way for a hero to be adorned with such an unwilting flower is to experience a fated death. That is why the alternative of death in a choice between *kÄ“res* â€˜fatesâ€™ is the desired choice for the hero to make. And that is why the meaning of *ká¸—r* defaults to â€˜a fated deathâ€™ as desired by heroes in the epic world of heroes. See again the overall comment on I.09.410â€“416. For Achilles, the *kleos aphthiton* â€˜unwilting gloryâ€™ that he chooses is really an alternative form of life, while the *nostos* â€˜homecomingâ€™ that he ultimately rejects is an alternative form of death, since the name of his homeland is *PhthiÄ“*, a â€œspeaking nameâ€ (*nomen* *loquens*) that means literally â€˜the land of wiltingâ€™. See the comment on I.01.155. See also HPC 168n67 on the ritualized idea of wearing garlands that are â€˜unwiltingâ€™ in a Thessalian ritual that honors Achilles. By contrast with the hero Achilles, however, who chooses *kleos* or poetic â€˜gloryâ€™ instead of a *nostos* â€˜homecomingâ€™, the hero Odysseus does not need to make a choice. In fact, as we will see in a future comment, Odysseus cannot even make such a choice, since he needs a *nostos* â€˜homecomingâ€™ to achieve his own *kleos* or poetic â€˜gloryâ€™, which will be â€˜a song of homecomingâ€™.

The *Litai*, goddesses of supplication personified, I.09.502, afflict with *atÄ“* a man who does wrong by showing cruelty to suppliants and rejecting their supplications, I.09. 510â€“512. In rejecting the *Litai*, one is rejecting the process whereby compensation can be awarded for damage sufferedâ€”and the word for â€˜damageâ€™ is *AtÄ“* personified at I.09.504 and I.09.505. Further, the punishment for such refusal is another round of *atÄ“* â€˜aberrationâ€™â€”this time suffered by the one who rejects the *Litai*, I.09.510â€“512. The story told by Phoenix about Meleagros and Kleopatra is introduced at the very beginning, I.09.524, by the expression *houtÅ* â€˜this is howâ€™, which conventionally introduces a discourse containing a moral message, such as a fable. The Greek word for such discourse is *ainos*, the meaning of which is impossible to translate by way of any single English word. For want of a better alternative, I define *ainos* pragmatically as â€˜coded wordsâ€™â€”a â€˜coded messageâ€™. In the case of the story told by Phoenix, it is intended to carry a moral message for Achilles. The story is described, already at I.09.524, as *klea andrÅn* | *hÄ“rÅÅn* â€˜the glories [*klea*] of men who were heroesâ€™. By convention, such an expression refers to song, especially to the medium of epic. We saw at I.09.185â€“191 a truncated version of this expression, *klea andrÅn*, â€˜the glories [*klea*] of menâ€™, I.09.189, and the performer in that context was Achilles himself, singing his song while accompanying himself on the lyre. The male hero in the story of Phoenix, Meleagros, is like Achilles. He too is angry at his community, and he too has withdrawn from fighting in a war, leaving his own people in desperate trouble. Those who are near and dear to him now approach Meleagros, imploring him to return to the fight and making their appeals to him as suppliants. The narrative arranges the order of the suppliants in terms of the heroâ€™s ascending scale of affection. Those who are starting off on the lower levels of this scale will be mentioned earlier, while those who end up on the higher levels will be mentioned later. So, the highest someone on this scale will be mentioned last. Near the top of the scale are the *hetairoi* â€˜companionsâ€™ of Meleagros, I.09.585, who are described at I.09.586 as *philtatoi* â€˜nearest and dearestâ€™ to him. So also Phoenix thinks that he and his fellow ambassadors, as companions of Achilles, should be placed at the very top of his ascending scale of affection. But the highest person on the ascending scale of affection for Meleagros turns out to be his wife, named Kleopatra, I.09.556. Her name fits the moral message of the story, since *KleopÃ¡trÄ* means â€˜she who has the glory [*kleos*] of the ancestorsâ€™. Thus Kleopatra is the very embodiment of the story described as *klea andrÅn* | *hÄ“rÅÅn* â€˜the glories [*klea*] of men who were heroesâ€™, since heroes are figured as stylized ancestors of the community. But the question is, what meaning will this story have for Achilles? For this hero, the top of his own ascending scale of affection will turn out to be Patroklos, whose full name, *PatroklÃ©Ä“s*, has the same meaning as the name of *KleopÃ¡trÄ*, but the two elements of the name, *kleos* â€˜gloryâ€™ and *pateres* â€˜ancestorsâ€™ are in reverse. Each of the two names is a â€œspeaking nameâ€ (*nomen loquens*), and both names mean â€˜he/she who has the glory [*kleos*] of the ancestorsâ€™. Further, as noted in the comment for I.09.185â€“191, the etymology of the name *PatroklÃ©Ä“s* can be adjusted by way of interpreting the component *klÃ©os* â€˜gloryâ€™ in the plural sense of the word, not only in the singular sense: â€˜he who has the glories [*klÃ©(e)a* of the ancestors [*patÃ©res*]â€™. And the same can be said for *KleopÃ¡trÄ*: â€˜she who has the glories [*klÃ©(e)a* of the ancestors [*patÃ©res*]â€™.

@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001:10.0
:citation_urn: urn:cts:CHS:Commentaries.AHCIP:Iliad.10.0.te6kMK6

At the very beginning of the Iliadic text of Rhapsody 10, we find an interesting claim in the accompanying annotations known as the T scholia, which stem from Homeric research ongoing in the ancient world. According to that claim, this *rhapsÅidÃ­Ä* had been composed by Homer separately, not as part of the *Iliad*, and the separate composition was later arranged, *tetÃ¡khthai*, by Peisistratos to fit into the *Iliad*. Such a sense of separateness in the content of Rhapsody 10â€”a separateness that was noted, as we have just seen, in the ancient worldâ€”is due at least in part to a basic fact: *the actions of heroes here take place at night, not in the daytime*. The tactics and even the ethics of nighttime warfare are in many ways different from the protocols of daytime warfare as narrated in the rest of the *Iliad*, and the differences are traced in the commentary of DuÃ© and Ebbott 2010. And I would add that there are cognate patterns of nighttime warfare in Iranian epic traditions: see Davidson 2013:95â€“97 (for relevant observations on the figure of Dolon in Rhapsody 10 of the *Iliad*, see also Davidson 1979). As for the ancient claim that Rhapsody 10 was supposedly inserted into a pre-existing series of 23 rhapsodies, I have serious problems even with the chronology of such a claim. Whereas Peisistratos of Athens lived in the sixth century BCE, the division of the *Iliad* and *Odyssey* each into 24 performance-units or *rhapsÅidiai* can now plausibly be dated as far back as the late eighth and early seventh century BCE: see Nagy 2015.12.24 following Frame 2009 ch. 11. My view here supersedes an earlier view of mine as noted in PasP 181â€“182, where I considered the era of Demetrius of Phaleron, late fourth century BCE, as a possible setting for the division of the *Iliad* and *Odyssey* into 24 *rhapsÅidiai*.

@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001:10.1-10.579
:citation_urn: urn:cts:CHS:Commentaries.AHCIP:Iliad.10.1-10.579.i2fKcGj
:created_at: 2020-03-12T16:44:31.952Z
:updated_at: 2020-03-12T16:44:31.952Z

There is a pronounced shift in mood in Rhapsody 10. Unlike the narratives in the rest of the *Iliad*, this narrative focuses on how heroes behave at nighttime, as distinct from daytime. What dominates now is a poetics of ambush, which is a different kind of warfare. And a prime exponent of such poetics is the wolfish figure of Dolon. My comments here on Rhapsody 10 are mere supplements to the extensive commentary of [DuÃ© and Ebbott 2010](https://chs.harvard.edu/CHS/article/display/4278).

In these verses, Agamemnon worries about the partiality shown by Zeus to Hector. According to Agamemnon, Zeus favors Hector because of the *hiera* â€˜sacrificesâ€™ offered by that hero to the god, I.10.046, and Zeus shows his favor by letting Hector win against the Achaeans. That is why the Achaeans now need to devise a *boulÄ“* in the specific sense of a clever â€˜planâ€™, I.10.043, which is *kerdaleÄ“* â€˜craftyâ€™, I.10.044â€”a plan that is crafty enough to counter the many baneful things that Hector will do to damage the Achaeans by way of his *mÄ“tis* â€˜mind, intelligenceâ€™, I.10.048. The idea of â€˜doing by way of *mÄ“tis*â€™ here at I.10.048 is expressed by the derivative verb *mÄ“tÄ«esthai* (aorist *mÄ“tÄ«sasthai*)â€”which is later picked up by the verb *mÄ“desthai* â€˜deviseâ€™ at I.10.52, referring again to the many baneful things that Hector will doâ€”or â€˜deviseâ€™â€”against the Achaeans. You would think, adds Agamemnon, that Hector was the son of some god or of some goddess, I.10.050. This wording about Hector evokes the reality of an ongoing antagonism between the goddess Athena and the hero Hector. Already at I.07.047, the wording of the seer Helenos is referring to such a reality: Helenos addresses his brother Hector by describing him as comparable to the god Zeus himself with respect to Hectorâ€™s qualities of *mÄ“tis* â€˜mind, intelligenceâ€™, and the wording of this description is a direct affront to the divinity Athena, who is the very personification of *mÄ“tis* â€˜mind, intelligenceâ€™.

The syntax of this expression *epâ€™ anthrÅpous*, meaning â€˜throughout humankindâ€™, is unusual in Homeric diction, since there are no obvious parallels to be found for the combination of the preposition *epi*, ordinarily meaning â€˜onâ€™, with the accusative of *anthrÅpoi* â€˜humansâ€™. @urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001:10.233-10.240
:citation_urn: urn:cts:CHS:Commentaries.AHCIP:Iliad.10.233-10.240.orLmbn8
