With the help of king Aeolus, keeper of the winds, Odysseus and his companions sail off from this kingâ€™s island, propelled by Zephyros, the West Wind, O.10.025. So, they are traveling from west to east. At O.11.0028â€“030, we see that they have already sailed for nine days, and then, on the tenth day, Ithaca finally comes into view. But now Odysseus falls asleep at the steering oar, and his companions make the human error of opening the Bag of Winds, so that their ships are blown back, east to westâ€”all the way back to where they started, to the island of Aeolus, O.10.031â€“055. Aeolus now refuses to help Odysseus and his companions any further, O.056â€“076, and, as they sail on, O.077â€“79, it is no longer clear where they are headed. No longer will they be propelled toward Ithaca by the favoring West Wind that Aeolus had provided for them earlier. Their sea voyage is now directionless, and, by the time their ship reaches the land of the Laestrygonians, they have already lost their navigational compass, since this land appears to be a twilight zone, O.080â€“086. The disorientation will only intensify later, after Odysseus and some of his companions manage to escape from the land of the Laestrygonians and sail to the island of Circe: see the comment on O.10.189â€“202.

:citation_urn: urn:cts:CHS:Commentaries.AHCIP:Odyssey.10.189-10.202.QXx6RTv

Odysseus here at O.10.189â€“197 confesses to his companions that he no longer knows where the sun rises or where the sun sets, O.10.190â€“192, and, accordingly, he expresses his own despair by questioning whether there will be for him any further access to *mÄ“tis* â€˜mind, intelligenceâ€™, O.10.193. So, the disorientation of Odysseus is linked with loss of *mÄ“tis*. Clearly, the mind of the hero is correlated here with the celestial dynamics of sunset and sunrise. See further the comment on O.10.190â€“102. (More on this subject in GMP 246.) In response to the heroâ€™s expression of despair, his companions weep uncontrollably, O.10.198â€“202, and now all they can think about are the horrors they remember having experienced in their encounters with the Cyclops and with Antiphates the Laestrygonian, O.10.199â€“200. The epithet for one of these two monsters here, the Cyclops, is *androphagos* â€˜man-eatingâ€™, O.10.200, which suits not only the cannibalistic Cyclops but also Antiphates the Laestrygonian, who as can see at O.10.115â€“116 is likewise a cannibal. These memories of cannibalism are most telling, since the name of the Cyclops is linked here with the *biÄ“* â€˜force, violence, strengthâ€™ of this monster, O.10.200. And the link surely extends to Antiphates the Laestrygonian. That monster too, like the Cyclops, is a negative exponent of biÄ“ â€˜force, violence, strengthâ€™. And such memories evoke the worst moments of the story of the Trojan War as narrated in the *Iliad*, as when Achilles himself expresses the ghastly urge to eat the body of Hector raw, I.22.346â€“347. See the comment at I.22.346â€“348; also at I.23.001â€“064. So, Achilles as the primary exponent of *biÄ“* â€˜force, violence, strengthâ€™ in the *Iliad* can be seen in this context as a foil for Odysseus as the primary exponent of *mÄ“tis* â€˜mind, intelligenceâ€™ in the *Odyssey*. Even the Iliadic contexts of *biÄ“* â€˜force, violence, strengthâ€™ are evoked here, since Cyclops at O.10.200 is described not only as *androphagos* â€˜man-eatingâ€™ but also as *megalÄ“tor* â€˜having a heart that is mightyâ€™. Similarly at O.10.106, in an attested variant of that verse, this same description applies also to Antiphates the Laestrygonian. Beyond these two attestations, this epithet *megalÄ“tor* â€˜having a heart that is mightyâ€™ occurs nowhere else in the *Odyssey*, whereas it occurs regularly as a conventional description of generic warriors in the *Iliad*. That is why I propose to describe the horrific visions of cannibals in the *Odyssey* as Iliadic nightmares.

|190 My friends, I am speaking this way because I do not know which place is west and which place is east |191 - which is the place where the sun, bringing light for mortals, goes underneath the earth |192 and which is the place where it rises. Still, let us start thinking it through, as quickly as we can, |193 whether there is still any craft [*mÄ“tis*] left. I must tell you, though, I think there is none.

(Epitomized from H24H 10Â§Â§38, 40, 42.) When Odysseus reaches the island of Circe and learns that this place, though it first seems familiar and reminiscent of his own island, is in fact strange and alien and antithetical to home, he despairs. As noted in the previous comment, the hero feels he has no intelligence or *mÄ“tis*  left in him to devise a stratagem for a successful homecoming, and his despair is expressed as a feeling of disorientation. He is no longer able to distinguish between orient and occident. To restate in terms of two words used elsewhere in the *Odyssey*, the hero is experiencing a loss of orientation in his *nÃ³os* or â€˜thinkingâ€™, and this loss is presently blocking his *nostos*, â€˜homecomingâ€™. Despite such moments of disorientation for Odysseus, however, his *nÃ³os*, â€˜thinkingâ€™ will ultimately reorient him, steering him away from his Iliadic past and toward his ultimate Odyssean future. That is, the heroâ€™s *nÃ³os* will make it possible for him to achieve a *nostos*, which is not only his â€˜homecomingâ€™ but also the â€˜song about a homecomingâ€™ that is the *Odyssey*.

|490 But first you [= Odysseus] must bring to fulfillment [*teleÃ®n*] another journey and travel until you enter |491 the palace of HÄdÄ“s and of the dreaded Persephone, |492 and there you all will consult [*khrÄ“*-] the spirit [*psÅ«khÄ“*] of Teiresias of Thebes, |493 the blind seer [*mantis*], whose thinking [*phrenes*] is grounded [*empedoi*]: |494 to him, even though he was dead, Persephone gave consciousness [*nÃ³os*], |495 so as to be the only one there who has the power to think [*pepnÃ»sthai*]. But the others [in HÄdÄ“s] just flit about, like shadows [*skiai*].

Circe describes for Odysseus what to expect when he sees Teiresias in HÄdÄ“s. Exceptionally, the *psÅ«khÄ“* â€˜spiritâ€™ of the hero, O.10.492, will have consciousness: that is, his *phrenes* â€˜thinkingâ€™ will be *empedoi* â€˜groundedâ€™, O.10.493. On *phrenes* in the sense of â€˜thinkingâ€™, see the anchor comment at O.01.320, where I note that Homeric diction leaves room for the idea that you can think with your heart. But what is it that confers on the *psÅ«khÄ“* â€˜spiritâ€™ of Teiresias the exceptional power to think even when he is dead, in HÄdÄ“s? The answer is given at O.10.494â€“495: Persephone, queen of HÄdÄ“s, has exceptionally given permission for Teiresias to have the *nÃ³os* â€˜consciousnessâ€™, O.10.494, that is needed for â€˜thinkingâ€™, *pepnÃ»sthai*, even in HÄdÄ“s. Here I translate *nÃ³os* â€˜mindâ€™ as â€˜consciousnessâ€™, referring to the mystical force that will reintegrate the consciousness of the self with the body after death. It is relevant that the *nÃ³os* or â€˜consciousnessâ€™ of the â€˜spiritâ€™ or *psÅ«khÄ“* of the seer Teiresias is properly activated only after he drinks the blood of two sacrificial sheep that Odysseus slaughters in order to make mental contact, as we will see at O.11.095â€“098. I offer further analysis in H24H 11Â§35. But there is a complication that I did not note in that analysis: Circe instructs Odysseus to perform a libation for the dead when he is in HÄdÄ“s, O.10.516â€“520, and he is further instructed to promise in a prayer directed at these dead that he will perform a sacrifice for them if he succeeds in getting back home to Ithaca: there Odysseus will slaughter a barren cow for the dead in general, O.10.522â€“523, and a black ram for Teiresias in particular, O.10.524â€“525. When the right time comes in HÄdÄ“s, and Odysseus performs his libations for the dead, O11.024â€“028, he will follow through and make that promise to them, namely, that he will sacrifice in Ithaca a barren cow for the dead in general, O.11.029â€“030, and a black ram for Teiresias in particular, O.11.032â€“033. (At H24H 11Â§35, I leave it unsaid that this black ram to be sacrificed in Ithaca is different from the black ram and black ewe that Odysseus sacrifices in HÄdÄ“s: see the comment on O.10.521â€“537.) As we know from external sources, such as Pausanias 5.13.1-2, a black ram is the preferred sacrificial animal to slaughter for the purpose of making mental contact with a male cult hero (H24H 0Â§11).

As Odysseus and his companions navigate toward the entrance to HÄdÄ“s, the atmosphere becomes ever darker. They are pushing the limits of the Extreme West, which the sun no longer illuminates. They are entering a zone where the sun can no longer be seen, O.11.015â€“016. Here the darkness that comes after sunset will be permanent, unlike the sunset that has already happened at O.11.012, which for the rest of the world will be followed by sunrise on the next day. But here, in this part of the world, the next day will never be found. Demarcating this zone, at the limits of the Extreme West, is the world-encircling cosmic river ÅŒkeanos, O.11.013.

Having arrived at the ÅŒkeanos, Odysseus and his companions beach their ship there and disembark, ÎŸ.11.020, proceeding to the place in HÄdÄ“s where Circe had instructed them to make sacrifice to the dead, ÎŸ.11.021â€“022. To get there, they go along the streams of the ÅŒkeanos, O.11.021. It is not said explicitly here that they have crossed the ÅŒkeanos in order to make their entrance into HÄdÄ“s, though the crossing is made explicit in the instructions of Circe at O.10.508. See the comment on O.10.508â€“512. Nor is it said that they will cross the ÅŒkeanos when they finally make their exit from HÄdÄ“s, O.11.636â€“640. When they do make their exit, Odysseus and his companions are pictured as reembarking on their ship and navigating it in the streams of the ÅŒkeanos, O.11.639â€“640, heading back to the sea that will take them back to the island of Circe. Then, at O.12.001â€“003, when they finally reach the sea again, from where they will navigate back to the island of Circe, this island is situated no longer in the Extreme West but in the Extreme East, O.12.003â€“004. So, by implication, they will have navigated all the way around the world by way of the ÅŒkeanos, from the Extreme West all the way to the Extreme East. This circumnavigation ends up at the same place where it started, at the island of Circe, but now this island is situated not in the Extreme West but in the Extreme East. So, the location of Aiaia, this island of Circe, is a *coincidence of opposites*. The achievement of such a coincidence by way of the ÅŒkeanos can be imagined as either a looping around the world or, better, a looping under the world: either way, the circular cosmic river ÅŒkeanos flows from West to East to West to East and so on forever. For more on coincidences of opposites, see the comments at I.01.423â€“425 and at O.01.022â€“026, O.10.135.

Here at O.11.029â€“036, Odysseus continues to follow the instructions of Circe as articulated earlier at O.10.521â€“537: in the course of offering his libation, in HÄdÄ“s, to the dead, Odysseus should also offer them a prayer, promising them that, if he succeeds in getting back home to Ithaca, he will then sacrifice there a barren cow for the dead in general, O.11.030â€“031, and a black ram for Teiresias in particular, O.11.032â€“033. And then, after having performed this prayer and these promises for all the dead, he sacrifices the two sheep that he and his companions have brought with them from the island of Circe: he cuts their throats, O.11.034â€“035, and then he lets their blood flow into the shallow *bothros* â€˜pitâ€™ that he has dug, O.11.036. Unlike O.10.526â€“527, where the sheep are said to be one black ram and one black ewe, those details are omitted here at O.11.034â€“035. Conversely, the detail at O.11.035â€“036 about the blood that flows into the *bothros* â€˜pitâ€™ from the cut throats of the sheep had been omitted at O.10.526â€“527. Likewise omitted at O.10.536â€“537â€”though it is impliedâ€”is the picturing of the dead in the act of actually drinking from the pit this blood that has flowed there from the cut throats of the sheep. Such drinking cannot happen, as Circe had instructed, until Teiresias arrives at the scene, O.10.536â€“537. And now that the blood has actually flowed into the pit, the instructions of Circe must be followed: no drinking of blood can be allowed until Teiresias arrives at the scene and drinks first, O.11.049â€“050. The very first word uttered by Teiresias is *nostos* â€˜homecoming, song of homecomingâ€™, O.11.100. The use of this word here is connected with the fact that, earlier in the narrative, the seer Teiresias is described as exceptionally possessing consciousness even in HÄdÄ“s, and the word used for the idea of consciousness is *nÃ³os*. The revelations of Teiresias are activated by his *nÃ³os* â€˜mindâ€™, in the specific sense of â€˜consciousnessâ€™. See the comment on O.10.490â€“495, with reference to the permission granted by Persephone for Teiresias to have the *nÃ³os* â€˜consciousnessâ€™, O.10.494, that is needed for â€˜thinkingâ€™, *pepnÃ»sthai*, even in HÄdÄ“s. It is relevant that the *nÃ³os* or â€˜consciousnessâ€™ of the â€˜spiritâ€™ or *psÅ«khÄ“* of the seer Teiresias is properly activated only after he drinks the blood of the two sacrificial sheep that Odysseus slaughters in order to make mental contact with this seer, as we see at O.11.095â€“098. What Teiresias will then reveal, by way of his *nÃ³os*, will be a heroic definition for Odysseus, whose goal is to achieve a *nostos* â€˜homecoming, song of homecomingâ€™, as signaled at O.11.100. See further the comment on O.11.100. For the centrality of *nÃ³os* â€˜mindâ€™ and *nostos* â€˜homecomingâ€™ in the overall narrative of the *Odyssey*, see especially the comments on O.01.003 and O.01.005.

:citation_urn: urn:cts:CHS:Commentaries.AHCIP:Odyssey.11.119-11.137.D9XKHxH

This stretch of the prophecy made by Teiresias, O.119â€“137, will extend beyond the plot or narrative frame of the *Odyssey* as we know it. (What follows is an epitome of H24H 11Â§Â§33, 41â€“44.) In an essay entitled â€œ*SÄ“ma* and *NoÄ“sis*: The Heroâ€™s Tomb and the â€˜Readingâ€™ of Symbols in Homer and Hesiodâ€ (GMP 202â€“222), I analyzed at some length the mystical prophecy spoken by the *psÅ«khÄ“* â€˜spiritâ€™ of the *mantis* â€˜seerâ€™ Teiresias at O.11.119â€“137 about an odyssey beyond the *Odyssey*. As I argued in that essay, the verses of this prophecy point to the future death of Odysseus and to the mystical vision of his own tomb, where he will be worshipped as a cult hero. My argument can be divided into four parts:

Part 1. Teiresias is predicting that Odysseus will meet his death in a mystical moment where he experiences *a* *coincidence of opposites*. And what is this mystical moment? It is a point where <u>the sea and the negation of the sea coincide</u>. That is, <u>Odysseus goes as far away as possible from the sea, only to experience death from the sea</u>: â€˜death shall come to you from the sea, |135 a gentle deathâ€™, O.11.134-135. See the comment below on these lines. At this same point, where the sea and the negation of the sea coincide, the oar that he carries on his shoulder, which is an instrument linked exclusively with the sea, will be mistaken for a winnowing shovel, which is an instrument linked exclusively with the earth, that is, with the cultivation of the land: â€˜Whenever someone on the road encounters you |128 and says that it must be a winnowing shovel that you have on your radiant shoulderâ€™, O.11.127-128. And here is another coincidence of opposites: Odysseus at this point must sacrifice to Poseidon, god of the sea, O.11.130-131, even though this point is as far away from the sea as possible.

Part 2. And now we come to a mystical vision: in sacrificing to Poseidon, Odysseus must mark the place of sacrifice by sticking into the ground the oar that he was carrying on his shoulder: â€˜at that point you must stick into the ground the well-made oarâ€™, O.11.129. As I will now argue, what we are seeing here is a mystical vision of the tomb of Odysseus himself. The key to my argument is what the *psÅ«khÄ“* of Teiresias says in introducing his prophecy: â€˜And I [= Teiresias] will tell you [= Odysseus] a sign [*sÄ“ma*], a very clear one, which will not get lost in your thinkingâ€™, O.11.126. The wording here matches exactly the wording of Nestor addressed to Antilokhos in the *Iliad*: â€˜And I [= Nestor] will tell you [= Antilokhos] a sign [*sÄ“ma*], a very clear one, which will not get lost in your thinkingâ€™, I.23.326. In that case, it can be argued that the *sÄ“ma* of Nestor for Antilokhos is a â€˜signâ€™ as marked by the â€˜tombâ€™ of a cult hero who has not yet been identified as Patroklos. See the comment on I.23.326â€“343. In the *Odyssey* as well, I argue, the *sÄ“ma* of Teiresias for Odysseus is a â€˜signâ€™ as marked by the â€˜tombâ€™ of a cult hero who has not yet been identified as Odysseus himself.

Part 3. There is archaeological evidence for the existence of a hero cult of Odysseus on the island of Ithaca, dating back to an early period when the *Odyssey* as we know it was still taking shape (H24H 11Â§43). And, in the version of the story as we see it in the *Odyssey*, Odysseus dies finally in Ithaca, which figures here as his homeland, O.11.132â€“137. In terms of this version of the story, then, Ithaca is recognized in the *Odyssey* as a prime location for the hero cult of Odysseus.

Part 4. This is not to say, however, that Ithaca was the only place where Odysseus was worshipped as a cult hero. From the testimony of Pausanias 8.44.4, for example, we see traces of a hero cult of Odysseus in landlocked Arcadia, which is located in the Peloponnesus and which is as far away from the sea as you can possibly be in the Peloponnesus. Here is the relevant testimony of Pausanias 8.44.4:

At O.11.330, Odysseus breaks off his performance, and the break continues till O.11.385, when the performance recommences. In between, there is a series of polite exchanges between Odysseus as performer and Alkinoos as the primary representative of the audience. The question is, has the duration of the performance become overlong? The answer is: no. On behalf of the audience, Alkinoos insists that Odysseus continue, and the master performer obliges.

Part 1. After his sojourn in HÄdÄ“s, which is narrated in *Odyssey* 11, here at the beginning of *Odyssey* 12 Odysseus finally emerges from that realm of darkness and death. As Odysseus now returns from HÄdÄ“s, crossing again the circular cosmic stream of ÅŒkeanos at O.12.001â€“002 and coming back to his point of departure, that is, to the island of the goddess Circe at O.12.003, we find that this island is no longer in the Far West: instead, it is now in the Far East, where HÄ“lios the god of the sun has his â€˜sunrisesâ€™, *an(a)tolai*, O.12.004, and where Ä’Ås the goddess of the dawn has her own palace, featuring a special space for her â€˜choral singing-and-dancingâ€™, *khoroi*, O.12.003â€“004. Before the heroâ€™s descent into the realm of darkness and death, we saw the ÅŒkeanos as the absolute marker of the Far West; after his ascent into the realm of light and life, we see it as the absolute marker of the Far East (GM 237). *In returning to the island of Circe by crossing the circular cosmic river ÅŒkeanos for the second time, the hero has come full circle, experiencing sunrise after having experienced sunset*. Even the name of Circe may be relevant, since the form *KirkÄ“* may be a â€œspeaking nameâ€ (*nomen loquens*), cognate with the form *kirkos*, a variant of the noun *krikos*, meaning â€˜circle, ringâ€™ (*DELG* under ÎºÏÎ¯ÎºÎ¿Ï‚). As we will now see, this experience of coming full circle is a mental experienceâ€”or, to put it another way, it is a psychic experience.

Part 2. The return of Odysseus to light and life replicates the mystical journey of the sun as it travels every night from the Far West to the Far East, and thus the heroâ€™s return becomes a substitute for the mystical journey of a soul. This way, the *nostos* â€˜returnâ€™ of Odysseus, as an epic narrative, becomes interwoven with a mystical subnarrative. While the epic narrative tells about the heroâ€™s return to Ithaca after all the fighting at Troy and all the travels at sea, the mystical subnarrative tells about the soulâ€™s return from darkness and death to light and life.

Part 3. In some poetic traditions, the mystical subnarrative of the heroâ€™s *nostos* can even be foregrounded, as in these verses of Theognis (1123â€“1128):

The kinds of things that happened to Odysseus have happened to me too. |1124 He came back, emerging from the great palace of HÄdÄ“s, |1125 and then killed the suitors with a pitiless heart [*thÅ«mos*], |1126 while thinking good thoughts about his duly wedded wife Penelope, |1127 who all along waited for him and stood by their dear son |1128 while he [= Odysseus] was experiencing dangers on land and in the gaping chasms of the sea.

Part 4. The return of Odysseus from HÄdÄ“s leads to a rebuilding of his heroic identity. Earlier in the *Odyssey*, the status of Odysseus as a hero of epic had already been reduced to nothing. As we saw in the tale of his encounter with the Cyclops, the return of Odysseus from the monsterâ€™s cave deprives him of his past identity at Troy. His epic fame can no longer depend on his power of *mÄ“tis*, â€˜craftâ€™, which had led to the invention of the Wooden Horse, which in turn had led to the destruction of Troy. After his encounter with the Cyclops, Odysseus must achieve a new epic identity as the hero of his own epic about homecoming, about his own *nostos*, but, for the moment, his confidence in his power to bring about this *nostos* is reduced to nothing. He has lost his confidence in the power of his own *mÄ“tis*, â€˜craftinessâ€™, to devise a stratagem for achieving a *nostos*. When he reaches the island of Circe and learns that this place, though it first seems familiar and reminiscent of his own island, is in fact strange and alien and antithetical to home, he despairs, as we saw at O.10.189-202.

Part 5. Despite such moments of disorientation for Odysseus, his *nÃ³os*, â€˜thinkingâ€™, will ultimately reorient him, steering him away from his Iliadic past and toward his ultimate Odyssean future. That is, the heroâ€™s *nÃ³os* will make it possible for him to achieve a *nostos*, which is not only his â€˜homecomingâ€™ but also the â€˜song about a homecomingâ€™ that is the *Odyssey*. For this song to succeed, Odysseus must keep adapting his identity by making his *nÃ³os* fit the *nÃ³os* of the many different characters he encounters in the course of his *nostos* in progress. In order to adapt, he must master many different forms of discourse. The epithet for this ability to adapt, as we will see, is *poluainos*, â€˜having many different kinds of coded wordsâ€™: that is how Odysseus is described by the Sirens when he sails past their island, O.12.184).

|14 We heaped up a tomb [*tumbos*] for him, and then, erecting as a column on top, |15 we stuck his well-made oar into the very top of the tomb [*tumbos*].

The story of Elpenorâ€™s death was told at O.10.551â€“560. In the comment on those verses, I already noted that the relevance of this figure to the homecoming of Odysseus is signaled at O.11.051â€“083, and, further, here at O.12.014â€“015. Here we see Odysseus and his men making for Elpenor a tomb by heaping a tumulus of earth over the seafarerâ€™s corpse and then, instead of erecting a *stÄ“lÄ“* or vertical â€˜columnâ€™ on top, they stick his oar into the heap of earth. (What follows is epitomized from H24HÂ§Â§47â€“50.)

Part 1. The ritual procedure for making the tomb of Elpenor follows the instructions given to Odysseus during his sojourn in HÄdÄ“s, O.11.051-080; these instructions were given by Elpenor himself or, more accurately, by his *psÅ«khÄ“* â€˜spiritâ€™, O.11.051, and the wording makes it explicit that the tomb to be made is a *sÄ“ma*, O.11.075.

Part 2. In the light of this description, we can see that the ritual act of Odysseus when he sticks his own well-made oar into the ground at O.11.129 and sacrifices to Poseidon at O.11.130-131 points to the making of his own *sÄ“ma* or â€˜tombâ€™, corresponding to the *sÄ“ma* or â€˜signâ€™ given to him by Teiresias at O.11.126.

Part 3. There are two meanings to be found in this ritual act of Odysseus, since he sticks his oar into the ground at the precise moment when the oar is no longer recognized as an oar, O.11.129. In this *coincidence of opposites*, the oar is now a winnowing shovel, O.11.128â€”an agricultural implement that is used for separating the grain from the chaff after the harvesting of wheat. You toss the harvested wheat up in the air, and even the slightest breeze will blow the chaff further to the side while the grain falls more or less straight down into a heap in front of you. The winnowing shovel looks exactly like an oar, but it is not an oar for agriculturists. Conversely, the oar looks exactly like the winnowing shovel, but it is not a winnowing shovel for seafarers. For Odysseus, however, this implement could be both an oar and a winnowing shovel, since he could see that the same *sÄ“ma* or â€˜signâ€™ has two distinct meanings in two distinct places: what is an oar for the seafarers is a winnowing shovel for the inlanders. And, in order to recognize that one *sÄ“ma* or â€˜signâ€™ could have two meanings, *Odysseus must travel*, as we see from the key wording he learned from the instructions of Teiresias. Odysseus himself is represented as the user of this key wording when he retells to Penelope a retrospective story of his travels, O.23.266â€“268. And, as we saw at O.01.003, the travels of Odysseus throughout â€˜the many cities of mortalsâ€™ were the key to his achieving his special kind of heroic consciousness, or *nÃ³os*.

Part 4. Just as the implement carried by Odysseus is one sign with two meanings, so also the picture of this implement that we see stuck into the ground is one sign with two meanings. We have already noted the first of these meanings, namely, that the *sÄ“ma* or â€˜signâ€™ given by Teiresias to Odysseus at O.11.126 is in fact the tomb of Odysseus, imagined as a heap of earth with an oar stuck into it on top, just as the tomb of the seafarer Elpenor is a heap of earth with his own oar stuck into it on top, as we just saw at O.12.14-15 and at O.11.075â€“078 respectively; in fact, as we saw O.11.075, this heap of earth is actually called the *sÄ“ma* of Elpenor, and the word here clearly means â€˜tombâ€™.

Part 5. Accordingly, I paraphrase the first of the two meanings as a headline, â€œthe seafarer is dead.â€ As for the second of the two meanings, I propose to paraphrase it as another headline, â€œthe harvest is complete.â€ Here is why: the act of sticking the shaft of a winnowing shovel, with the blade pointing upward, into a heap of harvested wheat after having winnowed away the chaff from the grain is a ritual gesture indicating that the winnowerâ€™s work is complete (as we see from the wording of Theocritus 7.155-156). And the act of sticking the shaft of an oar into the ground, again with the blade facing upward, is a ritual gesture indicating that the oarsmanâ€™s work is likewise completeâ€”as in the case of Odysseusâ€™ dead comrade Elpenor, whose tomb is to be a heap of earth with the shaft of his oar stuck into the top, as we see at O.11.075â€“078 and here at O.12.014â€“015. So also with Odysseus: he too will never again have to sail the seas.

|21 Wretched men! You went down to the House of HÄdÄ“s while you were still alive. |22 You are *dis-thanees* [= you experience death twice], whereas other mortals die only once.

Circe understands the mystical experience that Odysseus and his companions have undergone by entering HÄdÄ“s in the Far West and then returning from there in the Far East, just as the sun mystically travels from west to east during the night. That is why Circe, after Odysseus and his men arrive back on her island, addresses the whole group as *dis-thanees*, that is, â€˜those who experience death twiceâ€™. (What follows is epitomized from H24H 11Â§61.) So, Odysseus together with his companions had died metaphorically when he went to HÄdÄ“s in *Odyssey* 11 and then he had returned to light and life in *Odyssey* 12. But Odysseus will die for real in a future that is beyond the limits of the story told in the *Odyssey* as we have it: just as the seer Teiresias had predicted it when he gave to Odysseus a *sÄ“ma* or â€˜signâ€™ at O.11.126, Odysseus will die after he experiences another coincidence of oppositesâ€”while carrying the oar that becomes a winnowing shovel.

The ship Argo is Ï€á¾¶ÏƒÎ¹ Î¼Î­Î»Î¿Ï…ÏƒÎ± 'on-the-minds of all humans', because Homer himself has these things on his mind when he mentions them. This universalizing of the Argo,Â from the mind of the poet to the minds of all humans,Â makes sense only because thisÂ poetry assumes its own universal appeal as a given.

The verb Î¼Î­Î»Î¿Ï…ÏƒÎ± comes from the infinitiveÂ Î¼Î­Î»ÎµÎ¹Î½, which I translate with the wording 'to-be-on-the-mind-of'. The subject of this verb Î¼Î­Î»ÎµÎ¹Î½ is whatever is on the mind of someone. In everyday contexts, what is on the mind of someone is incidental: someone happens to be thinking about something, and so that something is on the mind of that someone. In Homeric contexts, however, whatever is on someone's mind is special and worthy of being recorded in poetry. This worthy something, then, as signaled by Î¼Î­Î»ÎµÎ¹Î½, isÂ more than just an incidental thought: it is a caring thought, a concerned thought, even a worried thought. A striking example comes atÂ *Iliad*Â 6.441, when, after Andromache says to Hector that she is thinking thoughts about the uncertain future that awaits her and their child, Hector responds that 'all these things are-on-my-mind [*melei*] as well' (á¼¦ ÎºÎ±á½¶ á¼Î¼Î¿á½¶ Ï„Î¬Î´Îµ Ï€Î¬Î½Ï„Î±Â Î¼Î­Î»ÎµÎ¹).

The translations â€˜of many fablesâ€™ or more simply â€˜fabledâ€™ reflect the specialized meaning of *ainos* as â€˜fableâ€™. In addressing Odysseus this way, the Sirens are recognizing the heroâ€™s fame as a master of *ainos*, which is a form of speech that can more generally be described as a *coded message* (on which see the comment on I.09.524â€“599). So, Odysseus is recognized as â€˜able to speak about many things *in* *code*â€™. Such coded speech is by nature â€˜riddlingâ€™, as we see from the meaning of *ainigma* â€˜enigma, riddleâ€™, which is a derivative of *ainos*. In order to survive, Odysseus must master many different forms of discourse, many different kinds of *ainos*. That is why he is addressed as *poluainos* â€˜having many different kinds of *ainos*â€™ by the Sirens here when he sails past their island, O.12.184. (What follows is epitomized from H24H 10Â§43.) Even the transparent meaning of Polyphemus, *PoluphÄ“mos*, which is the name of the Cyclops blinded by Odysseus, foretells the heroâ€™s mastery of the *ainos*. As an adjective, *poluphÄ“mos* means â€˜having many different kinds of things saidâ€™, derived from the noun *phÄ“mÄ“*, â€˜thing saidâ€™, as at O.20.100 and at O.20.105. See the comment at O.20.098â€“121, [HR]3Â§23. This adjective *poluphÄ“mos* â€˜having many different kinds of things saidâ€™ is applied as an epithet to the singer *PhÄ“mios*, O.22.376, portrayed as singing songs that have many different meanings: see the comments at O.01.342 and O.02.035 (see also BA 17). In the case of Polyphemus, the very meaning of his name, which conveys the opposite of the meaning conveyed by the false name of Odysseus, *Outis*, â€˜no oneâ€™, foretells the verbal mastery of the hero who blinded the monster.

|184 Come here, Odysseus, you of many riddling words [*ainoi*], you great glory to the Achaean name, |185 stop your ship so that you may hear our two voices. |186 No man has ever yet sailed past us with his dark ship |187 without staying to hear the sweet sound of the voices that come from our mouths, |188 and he who listens will not only experience great pleasure before homecoming [*nÃ©esthai*] but will also be far more knowledgeable than before, |189 for we know everything that happened at Troy, that expansive place, |190 â€”all the sufferings caused by the gods for the Argives [= Achaeans] and Trojans |191 and we know everything on earth, that nurturer of so many mortalsâ€”everything that happens.

Part 1. The two Sirensâ€”there are only two of them in the *Odyssey*â€”declare here that they know everything in generalâ€”but they also declare that they know everything about the Trojan War in particular. By knowing everything, they are like the Muses. The repeated word *idmen* â€˜we knowâ€™ at O.10.189/191 is comparable to what the Muses say to the Narrator in Hesiod *Theogony* 27/28, *idmen* â€˜we knowâ€™. Also comparable is what the Narrator says to the Muses at I.02.485: *iste te panta* â€˜you know everythingâ€™. By knowing everything about the Trojan War, the Sirens are like the Muses of the *Iliad*, as at I.02.485. It may be said that the Sirens are the false Muses of the *Iliad*.

Part 2. The Song of the Sirens is relevant to I.09.413, where Achilles says he will have to choose between a *nostos*, which is a safe â€˜homecomingâ€™, and the *kleos* or â€˜gloryâ€™ of the poetry that will be his if he dies young at Troy. See the comment on I.09.410â€“416. Achilles will have to forfeit *nostos* in order to achieve his *kleos* or â€˜gloryâ€™ as the central hero of the *Iliad*. By contrast, Odysseus must have both *kleos* â€˜gloryâ€™ and *nostos* â€˜homecomingâ€™ in order to merit his own heroic status in the *Odyssey* (BA 36-40). For him, the *nostos* is not only a â€˜homecomingâ€™ but also a â€˜song about a homecomingâ€™, and that song is the *Odyssey*. It is the *kleos* or â€˜gloryâ€™ of that song that will be hisâ€”if his quest for a homecoming is to succeed.

Part 3. (What follows is epitomized from H24H 9Â§14.) The narrative of the *kleos* or â€˜gloryâ€™ of song that Odysseus earns in the *Odyssey* cannot be the *Iliad*, which means â€˜tale of Troyâ€™ (Ilion is the other name for Troy). The *Iliad* establishes Achilles as the central hero of the story of Troy, even though he failed to destroy the cityâ€”while Odysseus succeeded, by devising the stratagem of the Wooden Horse. Because of the *Iliad* tradition, â€œthe *kleos* of Odysseus at Troy was preempted by the *kleos* of Achillesâ€ (BA 41). Thus the *kleos* that Odysseus should get for his success in destroying Troy is elusive, by contrast with the *kleos* that Achilles gets in the *Iliad*, which is permanent. So, Odysseus cannot afford to dwell on his success at Troy, because the *kleos* he may get for that success will become permanent only if it extends into the *kleos* that he gets for achieving a successful homecoming. Odysseus, then, must get over the *Iliad*.

Part 4. As we see from the wording of the Sirensâ€™ Song here in the *Odyssey*, O.12.184â€“191, the sheer pleasure of listening to a song about the destruction of Troy will be in vain if there is no *nostos*, no safe return home from the faraway world of epic heroes; and, by extension, the *Iliad* itself will become a Song of the Sirens without a successful narration of the *Odyssey* (BA [1999] xii).

Part 5. (What follows in Parts 5 and 6 is epitomized from H24H 10Â§Â§19â€“20.) So, to repeat, Odysseus must get over the *Iliad*. But, to get over the *Iliad*, he must sail past it. His ongoing story, which is the *Odyssey*, must be about the seafarer who is making his way back home, not about the warrior who once fought at Troy. The *kleos* of Odysseus at Troy cannot be the master myth of the *Odyssey*, since the *kleos* of Achilles at Troy has already become the master myth of the *Iliad*. As I already noted, the *kleos* or poetic â€˜gloryâ€™ of Achilles in the *Iliad* has preempted a *kleos* for Odysseus that centers on this rival heroâ€™s glorious exploits at Troy. For the hero of the *Odyssey*, the ongoing *kleos* of his adventures in the course of his *nostos* is actually threatened by any past *kleos* of his adventures back at Troy. Such a *kleos* of the past in the *Odyssey* could not rival the *kleos* of the more distant past in the *Iliad*. It would be a false *Iliad*. That is why Odysseus must sail past the Island of the Sirens. The Sirens, as false Muses, tempt the hero by offering to sing for him an endless variety of songs about Troy in particular and about everything else in general.

Part 6. The sheer pleasure of listening to the songs of the Sirens threatens not only the *nostos*, â€˜homecomingâ€™, of Odysseus, who is tempted to linger and never stop listening to the endless stories about Troy, but also the soundness of his â€˜thinkingâ€™, his *nÃ³os*. And it even threatens the ongoing song about the heroâ€™s homecoming, that is, the *Odyssey* itself (BA [1999] xii). Accordingly, the use of the verb *nÃ©esthai* â€˜return, have a homecomingâ€™ at O.12.188 signals what is at stake for both the *nostos* â€˜homecomingâ€™ and the *nÃ³os* â€˜mindâ€™ of Odysseus, and it is no accident that these two nouns are actually both derived from that verb.

The sacrificing of an ox to Zeus here marks this god as the ultimate hymnic subject of the festive performances starting with the three songs of Demodokos in *Odyssey* 8 and capped by the narrative of Odysseus himself in *Odyssey* 9â€“12. As we see most clearly in the *Homeric Hymns*, the invoked divinity who presides over a given festival is the hymnic subject of the hymn (MoM 4Â§82). We know from Pindar *Nemean* 2.1â€“3 that Zeus was the hymnic subject of the *HomÄ“ridai*, notional descendants of Homer, who performed the *Iliad* and *Odyssey* in relay (HPC 240, MoM 4Â§Â§99.4, 99.5). Accordingly, I interpret the sacrifice to Zeus here at O.13.024â€“025 as a signature, as it were, of the *HomÄ“ridai*. See also the comment that introduces Rhapsody 9.

|24 On their [= the Phaeaciansâ€™] behalf Alkinoos, the one with the holy power, sacrificed an ox |25 to Zeus, the one who brings dark clouds, the son of Kronos, and he rules over all. |26 Then, after burning the thigh-pieces, they feasted, feasting most gloriously, |27 and they were feeling delight [*terpesthai*]; in their midst sang-and-danced [*melpesthai*] the divine singer [*aoidos*], |28 Demodokos, honored by the people.

(What follows is epitomized from MoM 4Â§Â§35â€“38.)

Part 1. Here the singer Demodokos performs one last song before Odysseus leaves the land of the Phaeacians. The occasion is most festive, marking the conclusion of the overall festivities that had started in *Odyssey* 8â€”and had continued ever since then. Bringing these festivities to a spectacular close, Alkinoos the king of the Phaeacians slaughters a sacrificial ox to the god Zeus, and this animal sacrifice is the cue for Demodokos to emerge once again as the lead singer in the midst of a festive crowd.

Part 2. I note that the wording at O.13.027 is exactly the same as at O.04.017. See the comment on O.04.015â€“019. More important, we see the same wording also at I.18.604, which is the line that shows a part of the longer version of I.18.603â€“606. See the comment on I.18.603â€“604â€“(605â€“)606. In each one of these three lines that I just noted, O.13.027 and O.04.017 and I.18.604, a solo singer is shown, but the individuated soloist is leading into a choral song combined with dance, as signaled by the word *melpesthai* in all three contexts. This word, as we have seen, combines the idea of singing with the idea of dancingâ€”that is, choral dancing. That is why I translate *melpesthai* in a hyphenated format, â€˜singing-and-dancingâ€™. See also the comments on I.18.603â€“604â€“(605â€“)606 and O.04.015â€“019.

Part 3. The text of O.13.024â€“028 is a most decisive piece of comparative evidence validating the authenticity of the corresponding passage in the longer version of I.18.603â€“606. Both of these two passages show an individuated lead singer in the midst of a festive crowd surrounding a choral performance that brings delight to all. Both in O.13.027 and in I.18.604, the decisive word that shows the interaction of the individuated lead singer with choral performance is *melpesthai* â€˜sing-and-danceâ€™. (The verb *melpesthai* â€˜sing-and-danceâ€™ at I.18.604 is picked up by the corresponding noun *molpÄ“* â€˜singing-and-dancingâ€™ at I.18.606.) But the passage at O.13.024â€“028 occludes any direct mention of dancers, thus differing from the corresponding passage in the longer version of I.18.603â€“606, which highlights two individuated dancers as well as a chorus. Conversely, the passage in the shorter version of I.18.603â€“606 occludes any direct mention of a singer, thus differing from the corresponding passage in O.13.024â€“028 here, which highlights Demodokos as an individuated lead singer.

Part 4. The decisive evidence of this passage, O.13.024â€“028, is missing from the reportage of Athenaeus (5.181c) about the editorial decisions of Aristarchus concerning O.04.015â€“019 and I.18.603â€“606. And it is missing also from the argumentations of some who build theories about various kinds of textual interpolation. As I argued in the comment on I.18.603â€“604â€“(605â€“)606, the evidence of the wording at I.18.604â€“605 indicates that both the shorter and the longer versions result from formulaic variation.

|78 When they [= the Phaeacian seafarers] began rowing out to sea, |79 he [= Odysseus] felt a sweet sleep falling upon his eyelids. |80 It was a deep sleep, the sweetest, and most similar to death. |81 Meanwhile, the ship was speeding ahead, just as a team of four stallions drawing a chariot over a plain |82 speeds ahead in unison as they all feel the stroke of the whip, |83 gallopping along smoothly, with feet raised high as they make their way forward, |84 so also the prow of the ship kept curving upward as if it were the neck of a stallion, and, behind the ship, waves that were |85 huge and seething raged in the waters of the roaring sea. |86 The ship held steadily on its course, and not even a falcon, |87 raptor that he is, swiftest of all winged creatures, could have kept pace with it. |88 So did the ship cut its way smoothly through the waves, |89 carrying a man who was like the gods in his knowledge of clever ways, |90 who had beforehand suffered very many pains [*algea*] in his heart [*thÅ«mos*], |91 taking part in wars among men and forging through so many waves that cause pain, |92 but now he was sleeping peacefully, forgetful of all he had suffered. |93 And when the brightest of all stars began to show, the one that, more than any other star, |94 comes to announce the light of the Dawn born in her earliness, |95 that is when the ship, famed for its travels over the seas, drew near to the island.

(The following is epitomized from H24H 10Â§Â§11â€“12.) The very idea of *consciousness* as conveyed by *nÃ³os* is derived from the metaphor of *returning to light from darkness*, as encapsulated in the moment of *waking up from sleep*, or of *regaining consciousness after losing consciousness*, that is, of â€˜coming toâ€™. See the comment on O.01.003; also on O.09.082â€“104. This metaphor of *coming to* is at work not only in the meaning of *nÃ³os* in the sense of *consciousness* but also in the meaning of *nostos* in the sense of *returning from darkness and death to light and life*. See the comment on O.01.005. Remarkably, these two meanings converge at one single point in the master myth of the *Odyssey*. It happens here at O.13.078-095, when Odysseus finally reaches his homeland of Ithaca. Odysseus has been sailing home on a ship provided by the Phaeacians, against the will of the god Poseidon, and the hero falls into a deep sleep that most resembles death itself, O.13.079â€“080. This sleep makes him momentarily unconscious: he â€˜forgetsâ€™, as expressed by the verb *lÄ“th*-, O.13.092, all the *algea*, â€˜painsâ€™, of his past journeys through so many different cities of so many different people, O.13.090-091. Then, at the very moment when the ship reaches the shore of Ithaca, the heroâ€™s homeland, the morning star appears, heralding the coming of dawn, O.13.093â€“095. The Phaeacians hurriedly leave Odysseus on the beach where they placed him, still asleep, when they landed, O.13.119, and, once they sail away, he wakes up there, O.13.187. So, the moment of the heroâ€™s homecoming, which is synchronized with the moment of sunrise, is now further synchronized with a moment of awakening from a sleep that most resembles death.

|149 So now I want to smash the very beautiful ship of the Phaeacians |150 when it comes back, in a misty crossing of the sea, from its conveying mission, |151 so that these people [= the Phaeacians] will hold off, at long last, and stop their practice of conveying |152 humans. And I want to make a huge mountain envelop their city.

The god Poseidon is speaking, and he is very angry at the Phaeacians for providing Odysseus with one of their ships to convey the hero back to his home in Ithaca. The god now plans to take revenge, and he asks Zeus to approve his plan, which has two parts: (1) to smash the ship as it sails back home to the Phaeacians and (2) to make a huge mountain â€˜envelopâ€™ their city.

|155 When all the people of the city look out and see the ship sailing in, |156 turn it into a rock, just as it is about to reach land. |157 Make it look like a swift ship, so that people will look at it with wonder |158 â€”all of humanity will do so; and make the huge mountain envelop their city.

Before Zeus gives his approval, he modifies the terms of Poseidon&#x27;s two-part plan for vengeance. In the case of the first part, as we see here, the Will of Zeus is not that the ship be smashed but only that it be turned into a rock at the very moment that it sails into the entrance to the harborâ€”a rock destined to be a famous landmark for all time to come. In the case of the second part of the sea godâ€™s plan, it seems that Zeus will indeed allow Poseidon to make a huge mountain â€˜envelopâ€™ the city. We see here the precise wording of these two parts of the Will of Zeus, addressed as commands to Poseidon.

@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002:13.158
:citation_urn: urn:cts:CHS:Commentaries.AHCIP:Odyssey.13.158.D6cm2J5

(Epitomized from Nagy 2001:84â€“91, where bibliography is provided about various different views concerning this verse.)

According to the version of O.13.158 that survives only by way of Aristophanes, the future of the Phaeacians is not at all closed off. It remains open-ended, extending into the â€œpresentâ€ when the epic is being narrated. The threatening mountain will not block the harbor of the Phaeacians from the outside world â€”if we read *mÄ“de* â€˜but notâ€¦â€™ instead of *mega de* â€˜and a hugeâ€¦â€™ at O.13.158.

Two questions immediately come to mind. First, how could this different version fit the overall narrative of the Homeric *Odyssey*? Second, is the textual basis of this version â€œlegitimateâ€?

I already addressed the first question in the comments above, taking a close look at the logic of the narrative after O.13.158. Here I turn to the second question about O.13.158: is the textual basis of the different version featuring *mÄ“de* â€˜but notâ€¦â€™ really â€œlegitimateâ€? We can now add a related question: if it is legitimate, then does that delegitimize the version featuring *mega de* â€˜and a hugeâ€¦â€™?

Whether we need to choose one or the other variant depends on the way we look at Homeric poetry. If this poetry is merely a static text, then we are indeed forced to make a choice. If, however, we view Homeric poetry as a living systemâ€”an oral tradition that evolves ultimately into the textual tradition inherited by the Alexandrian editorsâ€”then we do not have to choose whenever we see a variation. Rather, as I will now go on to argue, the choices were already being made by Homeric poetry itself, which could opt for different variants in different phases of its own evolution.

My reasoning here derives from an overall â€œevolutionary modelâ€ that I have worked out as a general way of accounting for the making of Homeric poetry (PasP 109â€“114 and HQ 29â€“112). In terms of this model, as I now plan to argue, the living and evolving oral tradition of Homeric poetry itself allowed for a choice either to seal off its own past from the present time of narration or to reach into this present time and thereby make its presence fully manifest.

According to the narrative option linked with the first of our two variants from O.13.158, *mega de* â€˜and a hugeâ€¦â€™, the outlook is hopeless for the Phaeacians, since Poseidonâ€™s plan to seal off the city of the Phaeacians has been restated by Zeus and is therefore tantamount to the Will of Zeus, which the Homeric tradition conventionally equates with the way things ultimately turn out in epic narrative, as at I.01.005. At the beginning of the *Odyssey*, however, Zeus himself undercuts the equation of epic plot with the Will of Zeus, O.01.032â€“034. That is, there are differences in shades of meaning between the Iliadic and the Odyssean perspectives on the Will of Zeus as the plot of epic (PH 241â€“242).

According to the narrative option linked with the second variant *mÄ“de* â€˜but notâ€¦â€™, the outlook is still hopeful. After all, at an earlier point in the narrative, O.13.144â€“145, we can see a way out when Zeus tells Poseidon to exact any punishment he pleases â€˜if any human honors you not at allâ€™ (á¼€Î½Î´Ïá¿¶Î½ Î´á¾¿ Îµá¼´ Ï€ÎµÏ Ï„Î¯Ï‚ ÏƒÎµ â€¦ | Î¿á½” Ï„Î¹ Ï„Î¯ÎµÎ¹), O.13.143â€“144. The context is this: Poseidon has been angrily questioning Zeus, calling on him to explain the Will of Zeus (Î”Î¹á½¸Ï‚ Î´á¾¿ á¼Î¾ÎµÎ¯ÏÎµÏ„Î¿ Î²Î¿Ï…Î»á½µÎ½), O.13.127. That is, Poseidon calls on Zeus to explain the overall plot of the narrativeâ€”now that the Phaeacians have conveyed Odysseus back home to Ithaca. How can I be honored among the gods, Poseidon plaintively asks Zeus, â€˜when the Phaeacians do not honor me at all?â€™ (á½…Ï„Îµ Î¼Îµ Î²ÏÎ¿Ï„Î¿á½¶ Î¿á½” Ï„Î¹ Ï„Î¯Î¿Ï…ÏƒÎ¹ | Î¦Î±Î¯Î·ÎºÎµÏ‚), O.13.129â€“130. But then, as we have already seen in the comments, the story goes on to say that the Phaeacians will indeed initiate a remedy after the first disaster by proceeding to honor Poseidon with sacrifice in order to avert the second disaster, which is, the envelopment of their harbor by a huge mountain.

The narrative option that I link with the variant *mÄ“de* â€˜but notâ€¦â€™, according to which the Phaeacians are to be spared the second disaster of an all-enveloping mountain, depends on whether this variant as adduced by Aristophanes of Byzantium in place of *mega de* â€˜and a hugeâ€¦â€™ at O.13.158 is a genuine *formulaic* variant or only a *textual* variant. If it is the latter, then *mÄ“de* â€˜but notâ€¦â€™ may be just an editorial conjecture. That possibility would severely reduce the chances for arguing that *mÄ“de* â€˜but notâ€¦â€™ is a genuine alternative to *mega de* â€˜and a hugeâ€¦â€™. In what follows, however, I will argue against that possibility on several levels.

From an analysis of the formulaic system in which *mÄ“de* â€˜but notâ€¦â€™ is embedded, this form can be justified as a functioning element in that system, just as the form *mega de* â€˜and a hugeâ€¦â€™ is a functioning element: in other words, *mÄ“de* and *mega de* can be considered compositional alternatives in the formulaic system of Homeric diction.

As Leonard Muellner points out in a message written 1998.03.10 to me and to Chad E. Turner, *mega de* â€˜and a hugeâ€¦â€™ at O.13.177 is syntactically and formulaically parallel to *mÄ“de* â€˜but notâ€™ at O.13.183. In a message written 1998.02.03, Turner had pointed out to me that the metrical placement of *mÄ“de* â€˜but notâ€¦â€™  at O.13.198 is singular (although there are cases where this word straddles the last syllable of a spondee and the first syllable of a dactyl in the third and fourth feet, he finds no other cases in the second and third feet). But the formulaic system is capable of generating rare forms and combinations. For a striking example, we may compare the unique attestation of *mÄ“den* at I.18. 500: here is a word that is found this one and only time in the *Iliad* and the *Odyssey* put together, and yet it can be shown to be *formulaic*. See Muellner 1976:101â€“102, 106.

Moreover, there is immediate contextual as well as formulaic evidence to support the argument that *mÄ“de* â€˜but notâ€¦â€™ is a functioning compositional variant in the formulaic system. Let us consider the wording of Zeus in his answer to Poseidonâ€™s angry questioning at O.13.145:

|145 á¼”ÏÎ¾Î¿Î½ á½…Ï€Ï‰Ï‚ á¼Î¸á½³Î»ÎµÎ¹Ï‚ ÎºÎ±Î¯ Ï„Î¿Î¹ Ï†Î¯Î»Î¿Î½ á¼”Ï€Î»ÎµÏ„Î¿ Î¸Ï…Î¼á¿·

|145 Do as you wish and as was pleasing to your heart.

This open-ended wording of Zeus matches formulaically the wording of Alkinoos, when he had originally â€œquotedâ€ the prophecy of his father, O.08.570â€“571:

|570 á½£Ï‚ á¼€Î³á½¹ÏÎµÏ…á¾¿ á½ Î³á½³ÏÏ‰Î½. Ï„á½° Î´á½³ ÎºÎµÎ½ Î¸Îµá½¸Ï‚ á¼¢ Ï„ÎµÎ»á½³ÏƒÎµÎ¹ÎµÎ½, |571 á¼¤ Îºá¾¿ á¼€Ï„á½³Î»ÎµÏƒÏ„á¾¿ Îµá¼´Î·, á½¥Ï‚ Î¿á¼± Ï†Î¯Î»Î¿Î½ á¼”Ï€Î»ÎµÏ„Î¿ Î¸Ï…Î¼á¿·

|570 That is what the old man said. And the god [Poseidon] could either bring these things to fulfillment |571 or they could be left unfulfilled, however it was pleasing to his heart.

The formulation of Zeus, then, in leaving it still undecided whether or not the Phaeacians are to be â€˜envelopedâ€™, can be used as evidence to argue that *mÄ“de* â€˜but notâ€¦â€™ is indeed a genuine compositional alternative to *mega de* â€˜and a hugeâ€¦â€™.

As for the possibility that *mÄ“de* â€˜but notâ€¦â€™ is an emendation based on an editorial conjecture, my own cumulative work on Homeric variants as adduced by the three great Alexandrian editors of Homer (Zenodotus, Aristophanes, and Aristarchus) leaves me skeptical, since I find that these editors normally do not make emendations without manuscript evidence (PasP 107â€“152).

In making the specific argument that both variants *mega de* â€˜and a hugeâ€¦â€™ and *mÄ“de* â€˜but notâ€¦â€™ are genuine compositional alternatives, I return to my general argument that Homeric poetry is not a static text but a slowly evolving system. In terms of this general argument, the variant *mega de* produces a narrative closure for the Phaeacians: their fate is sealed. The variant *mÄ“de*, however, produces an outcome that is open-ended.

These two variants, I contend, reflect different phases in the evolution of Homeric poetry. Let us begin with the variant *mega de* â€˜and a hugeâ€¦â€™, the context of which can be linked with a relatively more Panhellenic phase of epic. (On the relativity of Panhellenismâ€”despite the absolutist implications of the termâ€”as a cultural impulse, see *PH* p. 53.) I have defined this phase elsewhere as one that â€œconcentrates on traditions that tend to be common to most locales and peculiar to noneâ€ (PH 54). The Panhellenic phases of epic make contact with the â€œpresentâ€ time of narration by shading over any â€œlocal colorâ€ that might distract from the widest possible range of ways to visualize this â€œpresentâ€ (PH 53). A Panhellenic version, then, will tend to universalize the concerns of the present.

But there are also other, less Panhellenic, ways for epic to make contact with the â€œpresentâ€ time in which narration happens: the â€œlocal colorâ€ can be highlighted, though only at the cost of narrowing the range of ways to visualize this â€œpresent.â€ The context of the variant *mÄ“de* â€˜but notâ€¦â€™ can be linked with such a relatively less Panhellenic phase of epic. This variant makes contact with the epic â€œpresentâ€ in a less universalized and more localized way. One focus of localization is historical Corcyra, modern-day CorfÃ¹.

The fact is, the Corcyraeans of the Classical period claimed to be residents of the land of the Phaeacians, as we know from a remark of Thucydides (1.25.4); from another remark of his, we know also that they worshipped King Alkinoos as their local cult hero (3.70.4).

In O.13.155â€“158, we hear how the Phaeacians will one day look out at their harbor and see their returning ship suddenly turn into a rock, and we hear also how that fabulous petrified ship will continue to be a most wondrous sight for future generations of humanity to see and to keep on seeing for all time to come. There are references to this â€œreal-lifeâ€ rock in Pliny (*Natural History*) 4.53 and Eustathius (Commentary on *Odyssey* vol. II p. 44 line 27), and to this day the â€œpetrified shipâ€ remains a most celebrated tourist attraction for visitors to CorfÃ¹. But the essential point is, the reference to this rock is already there in the *Odyssey*â€”that is, in a version of the *Odyssey* that says *mÄ“de* â€˜but notâ€¦â€™ instead of *mega de* â€˜and a hugeâ€¦â€™ at O.13.158.

The identity of the Corcyraeans as descendants of the Phaeacians depends on the Will of Zeus as he formulates it at O.13.155â€“158, and it depends especially on the variant *mÄ“de* â€˜but notâ€¦â€™ of O.13.158, which yields an open-ended narrative that reaches directly into the â€œpresentâ€ of the Classical period and beyond.

As a political and cultural fact of life, the self-identification of the Corcyraeans with the Phaeacians has been dated as far back as the eighth century BCE, when the island was settled by colonists from Eretria and, soon thereafter, from Corinth (Plutarch *Greek Questions* 293a; further sources analyzed in Frame 257n158). The variant represented by *mÄ“de* â€˜but notâ€¦â€™ at O.13.158 may be just as early, and in fact it may be the vehicle for expressing just such a political and cultural fact of life. This is not to say that the other variant represented by *mega de* â€˜and a hugeâ€¦â€™ at O.13.158 may not be just as early. It is only to say that both variants were still available to the Homeric tradition of epic as it evolved during the pre-Classical period. In such an early period, the affirmingâ€”or the denyingâ€”of a claim of descent from the Phaeacians was essential not just poetically but also politically and culturally. It really mattered then, and it continued to matter well into the Classical period of the fifth century and beyond, as we have seen from the remark of Thucydides (1.25.4, 3.70.4) about the Corcyraeansâ€™ claim that they inhabited the land of the Phaeacians, whose king, Alkinoos, they worshipped as their local hero.

In the Hellenistic period of the Alexandrian editors of Homer, by contrast, the question of choosing *mega de* â€˜and a hugeâ€¦â€™ or *mÄ“de* â€˜but notâ€¦â€™ would have mattered purely from a poetical rather than a political or cultural point of view. The Corcyraeansâ€™ claims to the land of the Phaeacians would not be a major concern any more, at least not politically. But it would still really matter in another way: was the petrified ship of the Phaeacians a figment of the poetic imagination, walled off in the epic past, or was it the same thing as the real-life rock at the entrance to the harbor of Corcyra, accessible to all humanity in the contemporary Hellenic world? The disagreement between Aristarchus and Aristophanes over the choice of *mega de* â€˜and a hugeâ€¦â€™ or *mÄ“de* â€˜but notâ€¦â€™ respectively must have centered on such questions. One way, we see a beautiful snapshot from the enchanted imaginary world of the epic past. The other way, we see a comparably beautiful vista in the enchanting touristic world of the non-epic present, still anchored in the permanence of the epic past. Either way, petrified ship or scenic rock, what we see is a beloved cultural landmark of Hellenism.

All this is not to say that we must ultimately choose between these two versions of seeing things Homeric. It is only to say that both variants were still available to the Homeric tradition of epic as it evolved into the Classical period and beyond. And it is to ponder the power of epic either to close down or to open up its pathways to the present. The fate of the Phaeacians in conveying the heroic past to the present depends on that power of Homeric dimensions.

There is some degree of non-matching, though: for example, the ship is Îµá½ÎµÏÎ³á½³Î± â€˜well-builtâ€™ in most manuscripts at O.08.567 vs. Ï€ÎµÏÎ¹ÎºÎ±Î»Î»á½³Î± â€˜very beautifulâ€™ in most manuscripts at O.13.175, while the mutually alternative forms are attested in a minority of manuscripts at both places. The Homeric narrative about the Phaeacians breaks off here at O.13.187, at the very moment when they are offering sacrifice and praying to Poseidon to take pity on them. The narrative break takes place most abruptly, dramatically, and even exceptionallyâ€”at mid-verse. In the first part of the verse at O.13.187, the Phaeacians are last seen standing around the sacrificial altar; in the second part of the verse, Odysseus has just woken up in Ithaca. A new phase of the heroâ€™s experiences has just begun in the â€œrealâ€ world of Ithaca.

@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002:14.1-14.533

Now that he has finally returned to his homeland of Ithaca, Odysseus must accomplish another kind of return: he must be restored to kingship. Such a restoration, however, must start from the bottom up. The goddess Athena, his ultimate benefactor but occasional antagonist, has made Odysseus seem to be â€˜baseâ€™ on the outside, hiding his inner moral nobility. Only those who are likewise morally â€˜nobleâ€™ will be able to read, as it were, the heroâ€™s true nature. Meanwhile, the coded tales told by Odysseus point toward the truth of his kingshipâ€”without revealing it outright. A telling example here in Rhapsody 14 is the second Cretan tale told by Odysseus: it is about a Cretan princeling, not unlike the dapper figure we see in the romanticized restoration of a Minoan fresco as featured in the cover-illustration for Rhapsody 14.

The wording at O.14.124â€“125 refers indirectly to itinerant poets/singers who are ready to adapt the content of their poetry/song to whatever the local audience expects to hear as its own local truth-value. It is as if such poets/singers were â€˜lyingâ€™, as expressed at O.14.125 by the verb *pseudesthai*, which is contrasted here in this line with the adjective *alÄ“the*- â€˜trueâ€™. Such itinerant poets/singers are described here as if they were wanderers in general who are ready to adapt the content of whatever they say to the standards of whomever they encounter in a given locale. By implication, those standards represent the real truth, while the mental process of adapting the truth is the equivalent of lying. Wandering beggars are like that: they will lie in order to please those who might give them food to express their pleasure. By implication, hunger for food in the stomach drives the poet as guest to say what his host wants to hear. The poet, then, is dependent on the patronage of his local audiences. See also the comment on O.07.215â€“221. There is a relevant passage in Hesiod *Theogony* 26â€“28, quoted in the comment on O.19.203.

I say-solemnly [*eukhesthai*] that I was born and raised in Crete, the place that reaches far and wide

(What follows is epitomized from Nagy 2017.04.11 5Â§Â§27â€“28.) Odysseus, disguising himself as a Cretan princeling, begins with a statement about his origins. He says he is from Crete. In the singular, *KrÄ“tÄ“* refers to the island of Crete. But here at O.14.199 we see the plural *KrÃªtai*, which cannot mean a multiplicity of islands named Crete. There is no such thing. Rather, we see here an elliptic plural, meaning â€˜Crete and everything that belongs to itâ€™. And of course whatever belongs to Crete are all the Aegean islands and lands controlled by the thalassocracy of Crete (HTL 163â€“164, following Muellner 1976:70). At O.19.178, we will see a pronoun that refers to Crete, and, like the noun *KrÃªtai* here at O.14.199, that pronoun too appears not in the singular but in the plural. So, again at O.19.178, we will see an elliptic plural. Also, in the comment on O.07.078â€“081, I noted a parallel example: it is the elliptic plural *AthÃªnai*, which means â€˜*AthÄ“nÄ“* and everything that belongs to itâ€™. My translation here shows â€˜itâ€™ instead of â€˜herâ€™ for a simple reason: the fact is, the singular form *AthÄ“nÄ“* refers not only to the goddess Athena but also to the place that she personifies. As we see at O.07.080, the noun *AthÄ“nÄ“* in the singular can refer not only to the goddess Athena but also to the place that she controls, which was primarily the acropolis of Athens. So, to put that singular form into the plural, which is an elliptic plural, is a way of referring to all the places controlled by the acropolis of Athens. Besides *AthÃªnai* in the sense of â€˜Athensâ€™, other such elliptic plurals include *MukÃªnai* â€˜Mycenaeâ€™ and *ThÃªbai* â€˜Thebesâ€™. See the comment on O.07.078â€“081 (see also, again, HTL 163-164). On ellipsis in general, see the comment on I.04.196; also on I.06.209, I.07.015â€“017.

(What follows is epitomized from HPC 289â€“290, where I offer supplementary bibliography.) A comparable pairing of Ares and Athena as divinities of war is found at I.18.515â€“519. See the comments on those lines. As I noted already in those comments, such a pairing of Ares and Athena is so old as to be traceable all the way back to the Bronze Age. Here I offer some details. As we know from the documentary evidence of the Linear B tablets found in the palace of Knossos in Crete, the divinities Athena and Ares (in that order) are paired as symmetrical recipients of offerings: in one tablet, V 52, a-ta-na-po-ti-ni-ja is listed together with e-nu-wa-ri-jo and pa-ja-wo-ne and po-se-da-o-ne. I interpret these syllabic spellings as follows: a-ta-na-po-ti-ni-ja = *AthÄnÄi potniÄi*Â or perhapsÂ *AthÄnÄs potniÄ *(see the comment on O.07.078â€“081), e-nu-wa-ri-jo = *EnÅ«aliÅi*, pa-ja-wo-ne = *PaiÄwonei*, po-se-da-o-ne = *PoseidÄonei*. As we know from the evidence of Homeric diction, the divine name *EnÅ«alios* became an epithet of Ares, as we see for example at I.18.211. In some Homeric contexts, as at I.20.069, *EnÅ«alios* is a god in his own right, distinct from Ares, just as *PaiÄwÅn* (Homeric *PaiÄ“Ån*) is in some contexts distinct from Apollo, as at I.05.401, I.05.899â€“900. As for the name of Ares, it too is attested in the Linear B tablets, Knossos Fp 14 and Fp 5816, in the form a-re = *Arei*. The Cretan connection of Athena and Ares is attested here at O.14.216 as well, where Odysseus in the second of his â€œCretan liesâ€ represents himself as a Cretan prince who professes his devotion to these two divinities in moments of crisis in battle. I should add that the pairing of Ares and Athena in the world of images represented on the Shield of Achilles is expressed by way of bronzework that is overlaid with gold, I.18.517â€“519. Such a technique of metalwork, as narrated on the Shield, is notionally linked to the heroic age or, as archaeologists would say it, to the Bronze Age.

Eumaios compliments the discourse of Odysseus, calling it a fine example of an *ainos*. Here the meaning of ainos can be interpreted in a general poetic sense, as â€˜coded wordsâ€™â€”a â€˜coded messageâ€™. But there is also a specific poetic sense that is conveyed by the same word: an *ainos* can be festive, highlighting the merriment of song and dance. The same kind of festivity is formalized also in the victory odes of Pindar, where the medium of the odes can refer to itself by way of the same word, *ainos*, as we see for example in the case of *Olympian* 11.7. See also the general comment on O.09.003â€“011 and the specific comment there on the word *euphrosunÄ“* â€˜festivity, merrimentâ€™ at O.09.006. On the programmatic implications of this word as an indicator of the festive atmosphere, as it were, of the poetic occasion, I refer again here to a definitive formulation by Bundy 1986:2 with reference to the poetics of Pindar (see BA 91, 235; also PH 198).

At O.13.439â€“440 it was said that the goddess Athena, after parting with Odysseus on the island of Ithaca, â€˜nextâ€™ went off to Sparta in order to connect with Telemachus there. The moment of that connection, which was going to happen â€˜nextâ€™, was expressed by way of the adverb *epeita*, O.13.439. Now at O.15.001â€“003 this moment that had been destined to happen â€˜nextâ€™ is finally at hand, and we see the goddess arriving at Sparta, where she will make it possible for Telemachus to connect mentally with his own *nostos* â€˜homecomingâ€™ to Ithaca, O.15.003. Essential here at O.15.03 is the use of the verb *hupo-mnÄ“-*, meaning â€˜mentally connectâ€™. The same verb is used in a comparable context at O.01.322. See the comment on O.01.320â€“322. Here at O.15.001â€“003, Telemachus will mentally connect not only with the idea of his own homecoming but also with the song of that homecoming, which will merge with the song of his fatherâ€™s homecoming. Telemachus needs to be mentally connected to his own *nostos* not only in the sense of â€˜homecomingâ€™ and â€˜song of homecomingâ€™ but also, more mystically, â€˜return to light and lifeâ€™. On this mystical meaning, see the comment on O.01.005, where this noun *nostos* is explained as meaning etymologically a â€˜returnâ€™ or a â€˜coming-backâ€™, derived from the verb-root **nes*- â€˜return, come backâ€™, which has a deeper meaning as well: â€˜come toâ€™, in the sense of â€˜come back to consciousnessâ€™. The noun *nostos* itself, meaning â€˜homecomingâ€™, likewise has a deeper meaning: â€˜coming back to light and lifeâ€™. Etymologically related to this noun *nostos* in the sense of â€˜coming back to light and lifeâ€™ is the noun *nÃ³os* â€˜mindâ€™, which has the deeper meaning of â€˜coming toâ€™ in the sense of â€˜coming back to consciousnessâ€™. As I argued in the comment on O.13.078â€“095, the idea of â€˜coming toâ€™ as embedded in the noun *nostos* is activated at the moment when Odysseus comes home to Ithaca: there he wakes up from a death-like sleep at the precise moment when the sun rises. To experience such a *nostos* as a â€˜homecomingâ€™, as I also argued in the same comment, is to experience a symbolic â€˜return to light and lifeâ€™, and the *Odyssey* as a â€˜song of homecomingâ€™ is such a *nostos*. Here at O.15.001â€“003, we see that the son of Odysseus must likewise experience a *nostos*, expressed here at O.15.003 not only by the noun *nostos* but also by the verb *nÃ©esthai*, derived from the root **nes*-. This line, O.15.003, shows that the song of this *nostos*, of this homecoming, is meant to merge with the song of the fatherâ€™s homecoming. See also the comment on O.01.088â€“089.

(What follows is epitomized from Nagy 2017.04.11 5Â§Â§29â€“31.) In the Homeric *Odyssey*, the Minoan-Mycenaean world is linked more directly to Sparta than to Crete. To make this point, I start with the beginning of *Odyssey* 15, where the goddess Athena appears in an epiphany to Telemachus at Sparta. As Athena tells Telemachus at O.15.001â€“009, it is time for the young hero to conclude his visit at Sparta and to go back home to Ithaca. I highlight the fact that Sparta is described here at O.15.001 as *eurukhoros* (Îµá¼°Ï‚ Îµá½ÏÏÏ‡Î¿ÏÎ¿Î½ Î›Î±ÎºÎµÎ´Î±Î¯Î¼Î¿Î½Î±), meaning â€˜having a wide dancing-placeâ€™. I see here a Minoan-Mycenaean signature. Relevant is the word *Kallikhoron*, which is explained this way in the dictionary of Hesychius: ÎšÎ±Î»Î»Î¯Ï‡Î¿ÏÎ¿Î½Â· á¼Î½ ÎšÎ½Ï‰ÏƒÏƒá¿· á¼Ï€á½¶ Ï„á¿· Ï„á¿†Ï‚ á¼ˆÏÎ¹Î¬Î´Î½Î·Ï‚ Ï„ÏŒÏ€á¿³ â€˜*Kallikhoron* was the name of the place of Ariadne in Knossosâ€™. And the meaning of this â€˜place of Ariadneâ€™, *Kallikhoron*, is â€˜the dancing-place that is beautifulâ€™. It is most relevant to highlight here the fact that the word *khoros* can designate either the â€˜placeâ€™ where singing and dancing takes place or the group of singers and dancers who perform at that place. Such a beautiful place, as we already saw in the comment on I.18.590â€“606, is made visible by the divine smith Hephaistos when he creates the ultimate masterpiece of visual art, the Shield of Achilles. At I.18.593â€“606, we see in action the singing-and-dancing that happens in the picturing of the divine place, the word for which is khoros, I.18.590. And the prima donna for such singing and dancing can be visualized as the girl Ariadne, for whom Daedalus had made the ultimate place for song and dance, I.18.592.

Here as also at O.15.253, it is said explicitly that the hero Amphiaraos died in the war of the Seven against Thebes. See also the note on O.15.253 (details in BA 204). (What follows is epitomized from H24H 15Â§34.) In the myth about the death of Amphiaraos as retold by Pausanias (1.34.2), the hero is riding back home on his war chariot after the defeat of the Seven against Thebes, when suddenly the earth opens up underneath and swallows himâ€”together with his speeding chariot and horses and allâ€”and, at the spot where this engulfment happened, there is a *hieron*, â€˜sacred spaceâ€™, where worshippers of the hero come to consult him, though Pausanias reports that there is some disagreement about matching the place of the ritual consultations with the actual place of the mythical engulfment. In any case, I propose that the engulfment of Amphiaraos by the earth signals not only his death but also his subsequent return from death as a cult hero. Here at O.15.247 and at O.15.253, the death of Amphiaraos after the expedition against Thebes is made explicit, though this death is only implicit in the references to the engulfment of the same hero as narrated in the songs of Pindar: *Olympian* 6.14; *Nemean* 9.24-27, 10.8-9. The poetic reticence we see in Pindarâ€™s songs about mentioning the actual death of Amphiaraos at the moment of his engulfment by the earth is a sign, I also propose, of a keen awareness about the subsequent resurrection of the hero (BA 154, 204).

The picturing of such an abduction is part of an overall mythological complex that I analyzed in some detail in GMP 242â€“245. I epitomize that analysis in what follows:

Part 1. Here is an inventory of verbs expressing the abduction of beautiful heroes by divinities:

A. Ä’Ås abducts Kleitos, here at O.15.250: *há¸—rpasen* â€˜snatchedâ€™

B. Ä’Ås abducts TithÅnos, *Hymn to Aphrodite* 218; *há¸—rpasen* â€˜snatchedâ€™ (on Ä’Ås and TithÅnos, see already the comment at O.05.001â€“002)
